DIV1.P: THE TRAGEDY OF THE DVTCHESSE Of Malfy. As it was Presented priuatly, at the Black-Friers; and publiquely at the Globe, By the Kings Maiesties Seruants. The perfect and exact Coppy, with diuerse things Primed, that the length of the Play would not beare in the Presentment.

Q.L: —Candidus Imperti si non his vtere mecum.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed by NICHOLAS OKES, IOHN WATERSON, and are to be sold the signe of the Crowne, in Paules Church yard, 1623.

LIST.ITEM: The Marquesse of Pescara, I. Rice.
The seuerall mad men, N. Towley. I. Vnderwood, &c.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE, GEORGE HARDING, Baron Barkeley of Barkeley Castle and Knight of the Order of the Bate To the Illustrious Prince CHARLES.
DIV1.P:
THAT I may present my excuse why, (being a stranger to your Lordshippe) I offer this Poem to your Patronage, I plead this war∣rant; Men (who neuer sa the Sea, yet desire to behold that regi∣ment of waters,) choose some eminent Riuer, to guide them thither; and make that as it were, their Conduct, or Postilion: By the like ingenious meanes, has your fame arriued at my knowledge, receiuing it from some of worth, who both in contemplation, and practise, owe to your Honor their clearest service. I do not altogether looke vp at your Title: The ancien'st Nobility, being but a rellique of time past, and the truest Honor indeede beeing for a man to conferre Honor on himselfe, which your Learning striues to
propagate, and shall make you arriue at the Dignity of a great Example. I am confident this worke is not vnworthy your Honors perusal for by such Poems as this, Poets haue kist the hands of Great Princes, and drawne their gentle eyes to looke downe vpon their sheetes of paper, when the Poets them∣selues were bound vp in their winding-sheetes. The like curtesie from your Lordship, shall make you liue in your graue, and laurell spring out of it when the ignorant scorners of the Muses (that like wormes in Libraries, seeme to liue onely, to destroy learning) shall wither, neglected, and forgotten. This worke and my selfe I humbly present to your approued censure. It being the vtmost of my wishes, to haue your Honorable selfe my weighty and perspicuous Com∣ment: which grace so done me, shall euer be acknow∣ledged

CLOSER.SIGNED: By your Lordships in all duty and Obseruance, Iohn Webster.

DIV2.HEAD: In the iust VVorth, of that well Deseruer, Mr. IOHN WEBSTER, and Vpon this Maister-peece of Tragoedy.

LG.L: IN this Thou imitat'st one Rich, and Wise,
That sees His Good Deedes done before he dies;
As He by Workes, Thou by this Worke of Fame,
Ha'st well prouided for thy Liuing Name;
To trust to others Honorings, is Worth's Crime,
Thy Monument is rais'd in thy Life Time;
And 'tis most iust; for euery Worthy Man
Is his owne Marble; and his Merit can
Cut Him to any Figure, and expresse
More Art, then Deaths Cathedrall Pallaces,
Where Royall Ashes keepe their Court: thy Note
Be euer Plainnes, 'tis the Richest Coate:
Thy Epitaph onely the Title hee,
Write, Dutchesse, that will fetch a teare for thee,
For who e're saw this Dutchesse liue, and dye,
That could get off vnder a Bleeding Eye.

LG.HEAD: In Tragaediam.
LG.L: Vt Lux ex Tenebris ictu percussa TONANTIS;
Illa, (Ruina Malis) claris fit Vita Poetis.

DIV2.HEAD: To his friend Mr. Iohn Webster Vpon his Dutchesse of Malfy.
DIV2.L: I Neuer saw thy Dutchesse, till the day,
That She was liuely body'd in thy Play;
How'ere she answer'd her low rated Loue,
Her brothers anger, did so far all prooue,
Yet my opinion is, she might speke more;
But (neuer in her life) so well before.

DIV2.HEAD: To the Reader of the Authour, and his Dutchesse of Malfy.
DIV2.L: CRowne Hi a Poet, whom no Rome, nor Greece,
Transcend in all their's, for a Master-peece:
In which, whiles words and matter change, and Men,
Act one anoher; Hee, from whose cleare Pen.
They All tooke life, To Memory hath lent
A lsting Fame, to raise hi Monument.

SP.SPEAKER: Delio.
SP.L: YOV are wel-come to your Country (deere Atoni)
You haue bin long in France, and you returne
A very formall French-man, in your habit.
How doe you like the French Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I admire it,
In seeking to reduce both State, and People
To a fix'd Order, there iuditious King
Begins at home: Quits first his Royall Pallace
Of flattring Sicophants of dissolute,
And infamous persons which he sweetely termes
His Masters Master-peece (the worke of Heauen)
Considring duely, that a Princes Court
Is like a common Fountaine, whence should flow,
Pure siluer-droppes ingenerall: But if 't chance
Some curs'd example poyson't neere the head,
"Death, and diseases through the whole land spread.
And what is't makes this blessed gouernment,
But a most prouident Councell, who dare freely
Informe him, the corruption of the times?
Though some oth'Court hold it presumption▪
To instruct Princes what they ought to doe,
It is a noble duety to informe them
What they ought to fore-see: Here comes Bosola
The onely Court-Gall: yet I obserue his rayling
Is not for simple loue of Piety:
Indeede he rayles at those things which he wants,
Would be as leacherous, couetous, or proud,
Bloody, or enuious, as any man,
If he had meanes to be so: Here's the Cardinall.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I doe haunt you still.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue done you
Better seruice then to be slighted thus:
Miserable age, where onely the reward
Of doing well, is the doing of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: You inforce your merrit to-much.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I fell into the Gallis in your seruice,
Where, for two yeares together, I wore two Towells in stead of
A shirt, with a knot on the shoulder, after the fashion of a
Romaine Mantle: Slighted thus? I will thriue some way:
Black-birds fatten best in hard weather: why not I,
In these dogge dayes?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Would you could become honest,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: With all your diuinity, do but direct me the way to it, I
Haue knowne many trauell farre for it, and yet returne as
Arrant knaues, as they went forth; because they carried
Themselues alwayes a long with them; Are you gon?
Some fellowes (they say) are possessed with the diuell,
But this great fellow, were able to possesse the greatest
Diuell, and make him worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: He hath denied thee some suit?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: He, and his brother, are like Plum-trees (that grow crooked
Ouer standing-pooles) they are rich, and ore-laden with
Fruite, but none but Crowes, Pyes, and Catter-pillers feede
On them: Could I be one of their flattring Panders, I
Would hang on their eares like a horse-leach, till I were full, an
Then droppe off: I pray leaue me.
Who wold relie vpon these miserable dependances, in expectation to
Be aduanc'd to morrow? what creature, euer fed worse, then hoping
Tantalus? nor euer did any man more fearefully, then he that hop'd
For a pleadon: There are rewards for hawkes, and dogges, and
When they haue done vs seruice; but for a Souldier, that hazards his
Limbes in a battaile, nothing but a kind of Geometry, is his last Supportation.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Geometry?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I, to hang in a faire paire of slings, take his latter-swinge in the
World, vpon an honorable pare of Crowtches, from hospitall
To hospitall, fare ye well Sir. And yet do not you scorne vs, for
Places in the Court, are but likes beds in the hospitall, where this
Mans head lies at that mans foote, and so lower, and lower.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I knew this fellow (seauen yeares) in the Gallies,
For a notorious murther, and 'twas thought
The Cardinall suborn'd it: he was releas'd
By the French Generall (Gaston de Foux)
When he recouer'd Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Tis great pitty
He should be thus neglected, I haue heard
He's very valiant: This foule mellancholly
Will poyson all his goodnesse, for (i'le tell you)
If too immoderate sleepe, be truly sayd
To be an inward rust vnto the soule;
It then doth follow want of action
Breeds all blacke male-contents, and their close rearing
(Like mothes in cloath) doe hurt for want of wearing.

STAGE.HI: Antonio, Delio, Ferdinand, Cardinall, Dutchesse, Castruchio, Siluio, Rodcico, Grisolan, Bosola, Iulia, Cariola.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: The Presence 'gins to fill, you promis'd me
To make me the partaker of the natures
Of some of your great Courtiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: The Lord Cardinalls
And other strangers, that are now in Court,
I Shall: here comes the great Calabrian Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Who tooke the Ring oftnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Antonia Bologna (my Lord)

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Our Sister Duchesse great Master of her houshold?
Giue him the Iewell: when shall we leaue this sportiue-action,
And fall to action indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Me thinkes (my Lord)
You should not desire to go to war, in person.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Now, for some grauity: why (my Lord?)

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: It is fitting a Souldier arise to be a Prince, but not necessary
A Prince descend to be a Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Noe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: No, (my Lord)
He were far better do it by a Deputy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Why should he not aswell sleepe, or eate, by a Deputy?
This might take idle, offensiue, and base office from him,
Whereas the other depriues him of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Beleeue my experience: that Realme is neuer long in quiet,
Where the Ruler, is a Souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Thou toldst me
Thy wife could not endure fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: True (my Lord.)

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: And of a iest, she broke of a Captaine;
She met, full of wounds: I haue forgot it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: She told him (my Lord) he was a pittifull fellow, to lie,
Like the Children of Ismael all in Tents.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Why, there's a wit were able to vndoe
All the Chyrurgeons o'the City, for although
Gallants should quarrell, and had drawne their weapons,
And were ready to goe to it; yet her perswasions would
Make them put vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: That she would (my Lord)
How doe you like my Spanish Gennit?

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: He is all fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I am of Pliny's opinion, I thinke he was begot by the wind,
He runs, as if he were ballass'd with Quick-siluer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: True (my Lord) he roles from the Tilt-often.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod. Gris.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Why do you laugh? Me thinks you that are Courtiers
Should be my touch-wood, take fire, when I giue fire;
That is, laugh when I laugh, were the subiect neuer so wity,

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: True (my Lord) I my selfe haue heard a very good iest,
And haue scorn'd to seeme to haue so silly a wit, as to vnderstand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: But I can laugh at your Foole (my Lord▪)

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: He cannot speake (you know) but he makes faces,
My Lady cannot abide him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Noe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Nor endure to be in merry Company: for she saies
Too much laughing, and too much Company, fils her
Too full of the wrinckle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I would then haue a Mathematicall Instrument made for
Her face, that she might not laugh out of compasse: I shall shortly
Visit you at Millaine (Lord Siluio.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Your Grace shall arriue most wel-come.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are a good Horse-man (Antonio) you haue excellent
Riders in France, what doe you thinke of good Horse-man-ship?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Noblely (my Lord) as out of the Grecian-horse, issued
Many famous Princes: So, out of braue Horse-man-ship,
Arise the first Sparkes of growing resolution, that raise
The minde, to noble action.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You haue be-spoake it worthely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Your brother, the Lord Cardinall, and sister Dutchesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Are the Gallies come about?

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.L: They are (my Lord.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Here's the Lord Siluio, is come to take his leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Now (Sir) your promise: what's that Cardinall?
I meane his Temper? they say he's a braue fellow,
Will play his fiue thousand crownes, at Tennis, Daunce,
Court Ladies, and one that hath fought single Combats.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Some such flashes superficially hang on him, for forme:
But obserue his inward Character: he is a mellancholly
Church-man: The Spring in his face, is nothing but the
Ingendring of Toades: where he is iealious of any man.
He laies worse plots for them, then euer was impos'd on
Hercules: for he strewes in his way Flatters, Panders,
Intelligencers, A thiests,: and a thousand such politicall
Monsters: he should haue beene Pope: but in stead of
Comming to it, by the primatiue decensie of the church,
He did bestow bribes, so largely, and so impudently, as if he would
Haue carried it away without heauens knowledge. Some good he Hath done.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: You haue giuen too much of him: what's his brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: The Duke there? a most peruerse, and turbulent Nature,
What appeares in him mirth, is meerely outside,
If he laugh hartely, it is to laugh
All honesty out of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Twins?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: In qualitie:
He speakes with others Tongues, and heares mens suites,
With others Eares: will seeme to sleepe o'th bench
Onely to intrap offenders, in their answeres;
Doombes men to death, by information,
Rewards, by heare-say.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Then the Law to him
Is like a fowle blacke cob-web, to a Spider,
He makes it his dwelling, and a prison
To entangle those shall feede him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Most true:
He neu'r paies debts, vnlesse they be shewed turnes,
And those he will confesse, that he doth owe,
Last: for his brother, there, (the Cardinall)
They that doe flatter him most, say Oracles
Hang at his lippes: and verely I beleeue them:
For the Diuell speakes in them.
But for their sister, (the right noble Duchesse)
You neuer fix'd you eye, on three faire Meddalls,
Cast in one figure, of so different temper:
For her discourse, it is so full of Rapture,
You onely will begin, then to be sorry
When she doth end her speech: and wish (in wonder)
She held it lesse vaine-glory, to talke much
Then your pennance, to heare her: whilst she speakes,
She throwes vpon a man, so sweet a looke,
That it were able raise one to a Galliard
That lay in a dead palsey; and to doate
On that sweete countenance: but in that looke,
There speaketh so diuine a continence,
As cuts off all lasciuious, and vaine hope.
Her dayes are practis'd in such noble vertue,
That, sure her nights (nay more her very Sleepes)
Are more in Heauen, then other Ladies Shrifts.
Let all sweet Ladies, breake their flattring Glasses,
And dresse themselues in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Fye Antonia,
You play the wire-drawer with her commendations.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I'll case the picture vp: onely thus much,
All her particular worth, growes to this somme:
She staines the time past: lights the time to come,

SP.SPEAKER: Cariola.
SP.L: You must attend my Lady, in the gallery,
Some halfe an houre hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Sister, I haue a suit to you:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: To me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: A Gentleman here: Daniel de Bosola:
One, that was in the Gallies.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Yes, I know him:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: A worthy fellow h'is: pray let me entreat for▪
The prouisorship of your horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Your knowledge of him,
Commends him, and prefers him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Call him heither,
Wee now vpon parting: Good Lord Siluio
Do vs commend to all our noble friends
At the Leagues.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Sir, I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are for Millaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: I am:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Bring the Carroches: we'll bring you down to the Hauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Be sure you entertaine that Bosola
For your Intelligence: I would not be seeene in't.
And therefore many times I haue slighted him,
When he did court our furtherance: as this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Antonio, the great Master of her houshold
Had beene farre fitter:

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You are deceiu'd in him,
His Nature is too honest for such businesse,
He comes: I'll leaue you:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I was lur'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: My brother here (the Cardinall) could neuer abide you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Neuer since he was in my debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: May be some oblique character in your face, made him suspect you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Doth he study Phisiognomie?
There's no more credit, to be giuen to th'face,
Then to a sicke mans vryn, which some call
The Physitians whore, because she cozens him:
He did suspect me wrongfully:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: For that
You must giue great men leaue to take their times:
Distrust, doth cause vs seldome be deceiu'd;
You see, the oft shaking of the Cedar-Tree
Fastens it more at roote.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yet take heed:
For to suspect a friend vnworthely,
Instructs him the next way to suspect you,
And prompts him to deceiue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Berd.
SP.L: There's gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: So:
What followes? (Neuer raind such showres as these
Without thunderbolts i'th taile of them;) whose throat must I cut?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Your inclination to shed blood, rides post
Before my occasion to vse you: I giue you that
To liue i'th Court, here: and obserue the Duchesse,
To note all the particulars of her hauiour:
What suitors doe sollicite her for marriage
And whom she best affects: she's a yong widowe,
I would not haue her marry againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: No, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Doe not you aske the reason: but be satisfied,
I say I would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: It seemes you would create me
One of your familiars.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Familiar? vvhat's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why, a very quaint inuisible Diuell, in flesh:
An Intelligencer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Such a kind of thriuing thing
I would wish thee: and ere long, thou maist arriue
At a higher place by't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Take your Diuels
Which Hell calls Angels: these curs'd gifts would make
You a corrupter, me an impudent traitor,
And should I take these they 'll'd take me Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Sir, I'll take nothing from you, that I haue giuen:
There is a place, that I procur'd for you
This morning: (the Prouisor-ship o'th' horse)
Haue you heard out?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Noe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: 'Tis yours, is't not worth thankes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I would haue you curse your selfe now, that your bounty
(Which makes men truly noble) ere should make
Me a villaine: oh, that to auoid ingratitude
For the good deed you haue done me, I must doe
All the ill man can inuent: Thus the Diuell
Candies all sinnes are: and what Heauen termes vild,
That names he complementall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Be your selfe:
Keepe your old garbe of melencholly: 'twill expresse
You enuy those that stand aboue your reach,
Yet striue not to come neere'em: This will gaine
Accesse, to priuate lodgings, where your selfe
May (like a pollitique dormouse,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: As I haue seene some,
Feed in a Lords dish, halfe a sleepe, not seeming
To listen to any talke: and yet these Rogues
Haue cut his throat in a dreame: whats my place?
The Prouisors-ship o'th horse? say then my corruption
Grew out of horse-doong: I am your creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let good men, for good deeds, couet good fame,
Since place, and riches oft are bribes of shame
Sometimes the Diuell doth preach. Exit Bosola.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: We are to part from you: and your owne dis∣cretion
Must now be your director.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are a Widowe:
You know already what man is: and therefore
Let not youth: high promotion, eloquence,

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: No, nor any thing without the addition, Honor,
Sway your high blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Marry? they are most luxurious,
Will wed twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: O ie:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Their liuers are more spotted
Then Labans sheepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Diamonds are of most value
They say; that haue past through most Iewellers hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Whores, by that rule, are precious:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Will you heare me?
I'll neuer marry:

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: So most Widowes say:
But commonly that motion lasts no longer
Then the turning of an houreglasse, the funeral Sermon,
And it, end both together.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Now heare me:
You liue in a ranke pasture here, i'th Court,
There is a kind of honney-dew, that's deadly:
'Twill poyson your fame; looke too't: be not cunning:
For they whose faces doe bolye their hearts,
Are Witches, ere they arriue at twenty yeeres,
I: and giue the diuell sucke.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: This is terrible good councell:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Hypocrisie is wouen of a fine small thred,
(Subtler, then Vulcans Engine: yet (beleeu't)
Your darkest actions: nay, your priuat'st thoughts,
Will come to light.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You may slatter your selfe,
And take your owne choice: priuately be married
Vnder the Eues of night.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Think't the best voyage
That ere you made; like the irregular Crab,
Which though't goes backward, thinkes that it goes, right,
Because it goes its owne way: but obserue;
Such weddings, may more properly be said
To be executed, then celibrated.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: The marriage night
Is the entrance into some prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: And those ioyes,
Those lustfull pleasures, are like heauy sleepes
Which doe fore-run mans mischiefe

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Fare you well.
Wisdome begins at the end: remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I thinke this speech betweene you both was studied,
It came so roundly off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are my sister,
This was my Fathers poyniard: doe you see,
I'll'd be loth to see't looke rusty, 'cause 'twas his:
I would haue you to giue ore these chargeable Reuels;
A Vizor, and a Masque are whispering roomes
That were neu'r built for goodnesse: fare ye well:
And woemen, like that part, which (like the Lamprey)
Hath neu'r a bone in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Fye Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Nay,
I meane the Tongue: varietie of Courtship;
What cannot a neate knaue with a smooth tale,
Make a woman beleeue? farewell, lusty Widowe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Shall this moue me? if all my royall kindred
Lay in my way, vnto this marriage:
I'll'd make them my low foote-steps: And euen now,
Euen in this hate (as men in some great battailes
By apprehending danger, haue atchieu'd
Almost impossible actions: I haue heard Souldiers say so,
So I, through frights, and threatnings, will assay
This dangerous venture: Let old wiues report
I wincked, and chose a husband: Cariola,
To thy knowne secricy, I haue giuen vp
More then my life, my fame:

SP.SPEAKER: Carolia.
SP.L: Both shall be safe:
For I'll conceale this secret from the world
As warily as those that trade in poyson,
Keepe poyson from their children.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thy protestation
Is ingenious, and hearty: I beleeue it.
Is Antonio come?

SP.SPEAKER: Cariola.
SP.L: He attends you:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Good deare soule,
Leaue me: but place thy selfe behind the Arras,
Where thou maist ouer-heare vs: wish me good speed
For I am going into a wildernesse,
Where I shall find nor path, nor friendly clewe
To be my guide, I sent for you, Sir downe:
Take Pen and Incke, and write: are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: What did I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: That I should write some-what.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh, I remember:
After this triumphs, and this large expence
It's fit (like thrifty husbands) we enquire
What's laid vp for to morrow:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: So please your beauteous Excellence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Beauteous? Indeed I thank you: I look yog for your sake.
You haue tane my cares vpon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I'le fetch your Grace the
Particulars of your reuinew, and expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh, you are an vpright treasurer: but you mistooke,
For when I said I meant to make enquiry,
VVhat's layd vp for to morrow: I did meane
VVhat's layd vp yonder for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: VVhere?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: In Heauen,
I am making my will, (as 'tis fit Princes should
In perfect memory) and I pray Sir, tell me
Were not one better make it smiling, thus?
Then in deepe groanes, and terrible ghastly lookes,
As if the guifts we parted with, procur'd
That violent distruction?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh, much better.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: If I had a husband now, this care were quit:
But I intend to make yon Ouer-seer;
What good deede, shall we first remember? say.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Begin with that first good deed, began i'th'world,
After mans creation, the Sacrament of marriage,
I'ld haue you first prouide for a good husband,
Giue him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: All?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes, your excellent selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: In a winding sheet?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: In a cople.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: St. Winfrid, that were a strange will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Twere strange if there were no will in you
To marry againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: What doe you thinke of marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I take't, as those that deny Purgatory,
It locally containes, or heauen, or hell,
There's no third place in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: How doe you affect it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My banishment, feeding my mellancholly,
VVould often reason thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Pray let's heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Say a man neuer marry, nor haue children,
What takes that from him? onely the bare name
Of being a father, or the weake delight
To see the little wanton, ride a cocke-horse
Vpon a painted sticke, or heare him chatter
Like a taught Starling.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Fye, fie, what's all this?
One of your eyes is blood-shot, vse my Ring to't,
They say 'tis very soueraigne, 'twas my wedding Ring,
And I did vow neuer to part with it,
But to my second husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You haue parted with it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Yes, to helpe your eye-sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You haue made me starke blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: There is a sawcy, and ambitious diuell
Is dauncing in this circle.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Remooue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: There needs small coniuration, when your finger
May doe it: thus, is it fit?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What sayd you? he kneeles

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sir,
This goodly roose of yours, it too low built,
I cannot stand vpright in't, nor discourse,
Without I raise it higher: raise your selfe,
Or if you please, my hand to helpe you: so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Ambition (Madam) is a great mans madnes,
That is not kept in chaines, and close-pent-roomes,
But in faire lightsome lodgings, and is girt
With the wild noyce of pratling visitans,
Which makes it lunatique, beyond all cure,
Conceiue not, I am so stupid, but I ayme
Whereto your fauours tend: But he's a foole
That (being a cold) would thrust his hands i'th'fire
To warme them.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: So, now the ground's broake,
You may discouer what a wealthy Mine,
I make you Lord off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh my vnworthinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: You were ill to sell your selfe,
This darkning of your worth, is not like that
Which trades-men vse i'th'City, their false lightes
Are to rid bad wares off: and I must tell you
If you will know where breathes a compleat man,
(I speake it without flattery) turne your eyes,
And progresse through your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Were there nor heauen, nor hell,
I should be honest: I haue long seru'd vertue,
And neu'r tane wages of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Now she paies it,
The misery of vs, that are borne great,
We are forc'd to woe, because none dare woe vs:
And as a Tyrant doubles with his words,
And fearefully equiuocates: so we
Are forc'd to expresse our violent passions
In ridles, and in dreames, and leaue the path
Of simple vertue, which was neuer made
To seeme the thing it is not: Goe, go brag
You haue left me heartlesse, mine is in your bosome,
I hope 'twill multiply loue there: You doe tremble:
Make not your heart so dead a peece of flesh
To feare, more then to loue me: Sir, be confident,
What is't distracts you? This is flesh, and blood, (Sir,)
'Tis not the figure cut in Allablaster
Kneeles at my husbands tombe: Awake, awake (man)
I do here put of all vaine ceremony,
And onely doe appeare to you, a yong widow
That claimes you for her husband, and like a widow,
I vse but halfe a blush in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Truth speake for me,
I will remaine the constant Sanctuary
Of your good name.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I thanke you (gentle loue)
And 'cause you shall not come to me, in debt,
(Being now my Steward) here vpon your lippes
I signe your Quietus est: This you should haue beg'd now,
I haue seene children oft eate sweete-meates thus,
As fearefull to deuoure them too soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: But for your Brothers?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Do not thinke of them,
All discord, without this circumference,
Is onely to be pittied, and not fear'd:
Yet, should they know it, time will easily
Scatter the tempest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: These words should be mine,
And a'l the parts you haue spoke, if some part of it
Would not haue sauour'd flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Kneele.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Hah?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Be not amaz'd, this woman's of my Councell,
I haue heard Lawyers say, a contract in a Chamber,
(Per verba presenti) is absolute marriage:
Blesse (Heauen) this sacred Gordian, which, let violence
Neuer vntwine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: And may our sweet affections, (like the Sphears)
Be still in motion.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Quickning, and make
The like soft Musique.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: That we may imitate the louing Palmes
(Best Embleme of a peacefull marriage)
That neu'r bore fruite deuided.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: VVhat can the Church force more?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: That Fortune may not know an accident
Either of ioy, or sorrow, to deuide
Our fixed wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: How can the Church build faster?
We now are man, and wife, and 'tis the Church
That must but eccho this: Maid, stand a part,
I now am blinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What's your conceit in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I would haue you leade your Fortune by the hand.
Vnto your marriage bed:
(You speake in me this, for we now are one)
We'll onely lie, and talke together, and plot
T'appease my humorous kindred; and if you please
(Like the old tale, in Alexander and Lodewicke)
Lay a naked sword betweene vs, keepe vs chast:
Oh, let me shrowd my blushes in your bosome,
Since 'tis the treasury of all my secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Whether the spirit of greatnes, or of woman
Raigne most in her, I know not, but it shewes
A fearefull madnes, I owe her much of pitty. Ex.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA I.
DIV2.STAGE: Bosola, Castruchie, an Old Lady, Antonio, Delio, Duchesse, Redorico, Grisolan.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You say you would faine be taken, for an eminent Courtice?

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: 'Tis the very maine of my ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let me see, you haue a reasonable good face for't already,
And your night-cap expresses your eares sufficient largely,
I would haue you learne to twirle the strings of your band with a
Good grace; and in a set speech, (at th'end of euery sentence,)
To hum, three, or foure times, or blow your nose (till it smart againe,)
To recouer your memory, when you come to be a president in
Criminall causes, if you smile vpon a prisoner, hang him, but if
You frowne vpon him, and threaten him, let him be sure to scape
The Gallowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: I would be a very merrie president,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Do not sup a nights, 'twill beget you an admirable wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cast.
SP.L: Rather it would make me haue a good stomake to quarrel,
For they say, you roaring-boyes eate meate seldome,
And that makes them so valiant:
But how shall I know whether the people take me
For an eminent fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I will teach a tricke to know it,
Giue out you lie a dying, and if you
Heare the common people curse you,
Be sure you are taken for one of the prime night-caps,
You come from painting now?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady.
SP.L: From what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why, from your scuruy face-physicke,
To behold thee not painted enclines somewhat neere
A miracle: These in thy face here, were deepe rutts,
And foule sloughes the last progresse:
There was a Lady in France, that hauing had the small pockes,
Flead the skinne off her face, to make it more leuell;
And whereas before she look'd like a Nutmeg-grater,
After she resembled an abortiue hedge-hog.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady.
SP.L: Doe you call this painting?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: No, no but you call carreening of an old
Morphew'd Lady, to make her disembogue againe,
There's rough-cast phrase to your plastique.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady.
SP.L: It seemes you are well acquainted with my closset?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: One would suspect it for a shop of witch-craft,
To finde in it the fat of Serpents; sawne of Snakes, Iewes spittle,
And their yong children ordures, and all these for the face:
I would sooner eate a dead pidgeon▪ taken from the soles of the feete
Of one sicke of the plague, then kisse one of you fasting:
Here are two of you, whose sin of your youth, is the very
Patrimony of the Physition, makes him renew his
Foote-cloth with the Spring, and change his
High-priz'd curtezan with the fall of the leafe:
I do wonder you doe not loath your selues,
Obserue my meditation now:
What thing is in this outward forme of man
To be belou'd? we account it ominous,
If Nature doe produce a Colt, or Lambe,
A Fawne, or Goate, in any limbe resembling
A Man; and flye from't as a prodegy.
Man stands amaz'd to see his deformity,
In any other Creature but himselfe.
But in our owne flesh, though we beare diseases
Which haue their true names, onely tane from beasts,
As the most vlcerous Woolfe, and swinish Meazeall;
Though we are eaten vp of lice, and wormes,
And though continually we beare about vs
A rotten and dead body, we delight
To hide it in rich tissew all our feare,
(Nay all our terrour) is, least our Phisition
Should put vs in the ground, to be made sweete.
Your wife's gone to Rome: you two cople, and get you
To the wels at Leuca, to recouer your aches.
I haue other worke on foote: I obserue our Duchesse
Is sicke a dayes, she puykes, her stomacke seethes,
The ins of her eie-lids, looke most teeming blew,
She waines i'th'cheeke, and waxes fat i'th'flanke;
And (contrary to our Italian fashion,)
Weares a loose-bodied Gowne, there's somewhat in't,
I haue a tricke, may chance discouer it
(A pretty one) I haue bought some Apicocks,
The first our Spring yeelds.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: And so long since married?
You amaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Let me seale your lipps for euer,
For did I thinke, that any thing but th'ayre,
Could carry these words from you, I should wish
You had no breath at all: Now Sir, in your contemplation?
You are studdying to become a great wise fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh Sir, the opinion of wisedome, is a foule tettor,
That runs all ouer a mans body: if simplicity
Direct vs to haue no euill, it directs vs to a happy
Being: For the subtlest folly proceedes from the
Subtlest wisedome: Let me be simply honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I do vnderstand your in-side.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Do you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Because you would not seeme to appeare to th'world
Puff'd vp with your preferment: You continue
This out off shashion mellancholly, leaue it, leaue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Giue me leaue to be honest in any phrase, in any
Complement whatsoeuer, shall I confesse my selfe to you?
I looke no higher then I can reach:
They are the gods, that must ride on winged horses,
A Lawyers mule of a slow pace, will both surt
My disposition, and businesse: For (marke me)
When a mans mind rides faster then his horse can gallop,
They quickly both tyre.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You would looke vp to Heauen, but I thinke
The Diuell, that rules i'th'aire, stands in your light.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh (Sir) you are Lord of the ascendant,
Chiefe man with the Duchesse, a Duke was your
Cosen German, remou'd: Say you were lineally
Descended from King Pippin, or he himselfe,
What of this? search the heads of the greatest riuers in
The World, you shall finde them but bubles of water:
Some would thinke the soules of Princes were brought
Forth by some more weighty cause, then those of meaner persons,
They are deceiu'd, there's the same hand to them:
The like passions sway them, the same reason, that makes
A Vicar goe to Law for a tithe-pig,
And vndoe his neighbours, makes them spoile
A whole Prouince, and batter downe goodly
Cities, with the Cannon.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Your arme Antonio, do I not grow fat?
I am exceeding short-winded: Bosola,
I would haue you (Sir) prouide for me a Littor,
Such a one, as the Duchesse of Florence roade in.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: The Duchesse vs'd one, when she was great with childe▪

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I thinke she did: come hether, mend my ruffe,
Here, when? thou art such a tedious Lady; and
Thy breath smells of Lymmon pils, would thou hadst done,
Shall I ound vnder thy fingers? I am
So troubled with the mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I feare to much.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I haue heard you say, that the French Courries
Weare their hats on fore the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I haue seene it.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: In the Presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes:
Why should not we bring vp that fashion?
'Tis ceremony more then duty, that consists
In the remoouing of a peece of felt:
Be you the example to the rest o'th' Court,
Put on your hat first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You must pardon me:
I haue seene, in colder countries, then in France,
Nobles stand bare to th'Prince; and the distinction
My thought show'd reuerently.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue a present for your Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: For me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Apricocks (Madam.)

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: O sir, where are they?
I haue heard of none to yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Good, her colour rises.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Indeed I thanke you: they are wondrous faire ones:
What an vnskilfull fellow is our Gardiner?
We shall haue none this moneth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Will not your Grace pare them?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: No, they tast of muske (me thinkes) indeed they doe:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I know not: yet I wish your Grace had parde'em:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I forgot to tell you the knaue Gardne,
(Onely to raise his profit by them the sooner)
Did ripen them in horse-doung.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch,
SP.L: O you iest:
You shall iudge: pray tast one.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Indeed Madam,
I doe not loue the fruit.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sir, you are loath
To rob vs of our dainties: 'tis a delicate fruit,
They say they are restoratiue?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: 'Tis a pretty
Art: this grafting.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: 'Tis so: a bettring of nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: To make a pippin grow vpon a crab,
A dampson on a black thorne: how greedily she eats them?
A whirlewinde strike off these bawd-farthingalls,
For, but for that, and the loose-bodied gowne,
I should haue discouer'd apparently
The young spring-hall cutting a caper in her belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I thanke you (Bosola:) they were right good ones,
If they doe not make me sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How now Madame?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: This greene fruit: and may stomake are not friend
How they swell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Nay, you are too much swell'd already.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh, I am in an extreame cold sweat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I am very sorry:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Lights to my chamber: O, good Antonio,
I feare I am vndone. Exit Duchesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Lights there, lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O my most trusty Delio, we are lost:
I feare she's falne in labour: and ther's left
No time for her remoue.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Haue you prepar'd
Those Ladies to attend her? and procur'd
That politique safe conueyance for the Mid-wife
Your Dutchesse plotted.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I haue:

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Make vse then of this forc'd occasion:
Giue out that Bosola hath poyson'd her,
With these Apricocks: that will giue some colour▪
For her keeping close.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Fye, fie, the Physitians
Will then flocke to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: For that you may pretend
She'll vse some prepar'd Antidote of her owne,
Least the Physitians should repoyson her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I am lost in amazement: I know not what to think on't. Ex.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. II.
DIV2.STAGE: Bosola, old Lady, Antonio, Rodorigo, Grisolan: seruants, Delio, Cariola.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: So, so: ther's no question but her teatchiues
And most vulterous eating of the Apricocks, are apparant
Signes of breeding, now?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady.
SP.L: I am in hast (Sir.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: There was a young wayting-woman, had a monstrous de∣sire
To see the Glasse-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Old La.
SP.L: Nay, pray let me goe:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And it was onely to know what strange instrument it was,
Should swell vp a glasse to the fashion of a womans belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Old La.
SP.L: I will heare no more of the Glasse-house,
You are still abusing woemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Who I? no, onely (by the way now and then) mention
Your fraileties. The Orrenge tree beare ripe and greene
Fruit▪ and blossoms altogether: And some of you giue entertainment
For pure loue: but more, for more precious reward. The lusty
Spring smels well: but drooping Autumne tasts well: If we
Haue the same golden showres, that rained in the time of Iupiter
The Thunderer: you haue the same Danes still, to hold vp their
Laps to receiue them: didst thou neuer study the Mathematiques?

SP.SPEAKER: Old La.
SP.L: What's that (Sir.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why, to know the trick how to make a many lines meete
In one center: Goe goe; giue your foster-daughters good councel
Tell them, that the Diuell takes delight to hang a womans girdle;
Like a false rusty watch that she cannot discerne how
The time passes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Shht vp the Court gates:

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Why sir? what's the danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Shut vp the Posternes presently: and call
All the Officers o'th' Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.L: I shall instantly:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Who keepes the key o'th' Parke-gate?

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Forobosco.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Let him bring't presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Seruant.
SP.L: Oh, Gentlemen, o'th' Court, the fowlest treason.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: If that these Apricocks should be poysond, now;
Without my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: There was taken euen now a Switzer
In the Duchesse Bed-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Seru.
SP.L: A Switzer?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: With a Pistoll in his great cod-piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Hh, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: The cod-piece was the case for't.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Ser.
SP.L: There was a cunning traitor.
Who would haue search'd his cod-piece?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: True, if he had kept out of the Ladies chambers:
And all the mowldes of his buttons, were leaden bullets.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Seru.
SP.L: Oh wicked Caniball: a fire-lock in's cod-piece?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: 'Twas a French plot vpon my life.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Ser.
SP.L: To see what the Diuell can doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: All the Offices here?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: We are:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Gentlemen,
We haue lost much Plate you know; and but this euening
Iewels, to the value of foure thousand Duckets
Are missing in the Ducthesse Cabinet,
Are the Gates shut?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Tis the Duchesse pleasure
Each Officer be lock'd into his chamber
Till the Sun-rysing: and to send the keyes
Of all their chests, and of their outward doores
Into her bed-chamber: She is very sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: At her pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: She intreates you take't not ill: The Innocent
Shall be the more approu'd by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Gentleman o'th' Wood-yard, where's your Swit∣zer now?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: By this hand 'twas creadably reported by one o'th' Black-guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: How fares it with the Dutchesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: She's expos'd
Vnto the worst of torture, paine, and feare;

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Speake to her all happy comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How I do play the foole with mine own danger?
You are this night (deere friend) to poast to Rome,
My life lies in your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Doe not doubt me,

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh, 'Tis farre from me: and yet feare presents me
Somewhat that looke like danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Beleeue it,
'Tis but the shadow of your feare, no more:
How superstitiously we mind our euils?
The throwing downe salt, or crossing of a Hare;
Bleeding at nose, the stumbling of a horse:
Or singing of a Criket, are of powre
To daunt whole man in vs: Sir, fare you well:
I wish you all the ioyes of a bless'd Father;
And (for my faith) lay this vnto your brest,
Old friends (like old swords) still are trusted best.

SP.SPEAKER: Cariola.
SP.L: Sir, you are the happy father of a sonne,
Your wife commends him to you.
Blessed comfort:
For heauen-sake tend her well: I'll presently
Goe set a figure for's Natiuitie. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Sure I did heare a woman shreike: list, hah?
And the sound came (if I receiu'd it right)
From the Dutchesse lodgings: ther's some stratagem,
In the conyning all our Courtiers
To their seuerall wards: I must haue part of it,
My Intelligence will freize else: List againe,
It may be 'twas the mellencholly bird,
(Best friend of silence, and of solitarines)
The Oowle, that schream'd so: hah? Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I heard some noyse: whose there? what art thou? speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Antonio? Put not your face; nor body
To such a forc'd expression of feare,
I am Bosola; your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Bosola?
(This Moale do's vndermine me) heard you no
A noyce euen now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: From whence?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: From the Duchesse lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Not I: did you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I did: or else I dream'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let's walke towards it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: No: It may be, 'twas
But the rising of the winde:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Very likely:
Me thinkes 'tis very cold, and yet you sweat.
You looke wildly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I haue bin sing a figure
For the Dutchesse Iewells;

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Ah: and how falls your question?
Doe you ind it radicall?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What's that to you?
'Tis rather to be question'd what designe
(When all men were commanded to their lodgings)
Makes you a night-walker.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: In sooth I'll tell you:
Now all the Court's asleepe, I thought the Diuell
Had least to doe here; I came to say my prayers,
And if it doe offend you, I doe so,
You are a fine Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: This fellow will vndoe me;
You gaue the Dutchesse Apricocks to day,
Pray heauen they were not poysond?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Poysond? a spanish figge
For the imputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Traitors are euer confident,
Till they are discouer'd: There were Iewels stolne too,
In my conceit, none are to be suspected
More then your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You are a false steward.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Sawey slaue: I'll pull thee vp by the rootes;

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: May be the ruyne will crush you to peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You are an impudent snake indeed (sir)
Are you scarce warme, and doe you shew your sting?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You Libell well (sir.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: No (sir,)
Copy it out: and I will set my hand to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My nose bleedes: One that were superstitious, would coun
This ominous: when it meerely comes by chance.
Two letters, that are wrought here, for my name
Are drown'd in blood: meere accedent: for you (sir) I'll take order:
I'th morne you shall be safe: 'tis that must colour
Her lying-in: sir, this doore you passe not:
I doe not hold it fit, that you come neere
The Dutchesse lodgings, till you haue quite your selfe;
The Great are like the Base; nay, they are the same.
When they seeke shamefull waies, to auoid shame. Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Antonio here about, did drop a Paper,
Some of your helpe (falce-friend) oh, here it is:
What's here? a childes Natiuitie calculated?
SP.P: The Dutchesse was deliuer'd of a Sonne, 'tweene the houres twelue, and one, in the night▪ Anno Dom: 1504. (that's this yeere) decimo nono Decembris, (that's this night) taken according to the Meridian of Malfy (that's our Dutchesse: happy discouery) The Lord of the first house, being combust in the ascendant, signifies short life: and Mars being in a human igne, ioyn'd to the taile of the Dra∣gon, in the eight house, doth threaten a violent death; Caeteta non scrutantur.
SP.L: Why now 'tis most apparant: This precise fellow
Is the Dutchesse Bawde: I haue it to my wish:
This is a parcell of Intelligency
Our Courtiers were caside-vp for? It needes must follow,
That I must be committed, on pretence
Of poysoning her: which I'll endure, and laugh at:
If one could find the father now: but that
Time will discouer; Old Castruchio
I'th morning poasts to Rome; by him I'll send
A Letter, that shall make her brothers Galls
Ore-flowe their Liuours, this was a thrifty way.

L.HI: Though Lust doe masque in nea'r so strange disguise,
She's oft found witty, but is neuer wise.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. IIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Cardinall, and Iulia, Seruant, and Delio.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Sit: thou art my best of wishes, pre-thee tell me
What tricke didst thou inuent to come to Rome,
Without thy husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Why, (my Lord) I told him
I came to visit an old Anchorite
Heare, for deuotion

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Thou art a witty false one:
I meane to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You haue preuailed with me
Beyond my strongest thoughts: I would not now
Find you inconstant.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Doe not put thy selfe
To such a voluntary torture: which proceedes
Out of your owne guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul,
SP.L: How (my Lord?)

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You feare my constancy, because you haue ap∣proou'd
Those giddy and wild turning in your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Did you ere find them?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Sooth generally for woemen;
A man might striue to make glasse male-able,
Ere he should make them fixed.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: So, (my Lord)

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: We had need goe borrow that fantastique glasse
Inuented by Galileo the Florentine,
To view an other spacious world i'th' Moone,
And looke to finde a constant woman there.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: This is very well (my Lord.)

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Why do you weepe?
Are teares your iustification? the selfe-same teares
Will fall into your husbands bosome, (Lady)
With a loud protestation, that you loue him
Aboue the world: Come, i'll loue you wisely,
That's iealously, since I am very certaine
You cannot me make cuckould.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I'll go home
To my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You may thanke me, (Lady)
I haue taken you off your mellancholly pearch,
Boare you vpon my fist, and shew'd you 'game,
And let you flie at it: I pray the kisse me,
VVhen thou was't with thy husband, thou was't watch'd
Like a tame Ellephant: (still you are to thanke me)
Thou hadst onely kisses from him, and high feeding,
But what delight was that? 'twas iust like one
That hath a little lingring on the Lute,
Yet cannot tune it: (still you are to thanke me.)

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You told me of a piteous wound i'th'heart,
And a sicke liuour, when you woed me first,
And spake like one in physicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Who's that?
Rest firme, for my affection to thee,
Lightning moones low to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: (Madam) a Gentleman
That's come post from Malfy, desires to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Let him enter, i'll with-draw. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: He sayes,
Your husband▪ (old Castruchio) is come to Rome,
Mst pittifully tyr'd with riding post.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Signior Delio? 'tis one of my old Suitors

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I was bold to come and see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Sir, your are wel-come.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Do you lie here?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Sure, your owne experience
Will satisfie you no, our Romane Prelates
Do not keepe lodging, for Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Very well:
I haue brought you no comendations from your husband▪
For I know none by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I heare he's come to Rome?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I neuer knew man, and beast, of a horse, and a knight,
So weary of each other, if he had had a good backe,
He would haue vndertooke to haue borne his horse,
His breech was so pittifully sore.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Your laughter,
Is my pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Lady, I know not whether
You want mony, but I haue brought you some.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: From my husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: No, from mine owne allowance.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I must heare the condition, ere I be bound to take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Looke on't, 'tis gold, hath it not a fine colour?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I haue a Bird more beautifull.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Try the sound on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: A Lute-string far exceedes it,
It hath no smell, like Cassia, or Cyut,
Nor is it phisicall, though some fond Doctors
Perswade vs, seeth's in Cullisses, i'le tell you,
This is a Creature bred by—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Your husband's come,
Hath deliuer'd a letter to the Duke of Calabria, that,
To my thinking hath put him out of his wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Sir, you heare,
'Pray let me know your busines, and your suite,
As briefely as can be.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: With good speed, I would wish you
(At such time, as you are non-resident
With your husband) my mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Sir, i'le go aske my husband if I shall,
And straight returne your answere. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Very fine,
Is this her wit, or honesty that speakes thus?
I heard one say the Duke was highly mou'd
With a letter sent from Malfy: I doe feare
Antonio is betray'd: how fearefully
Shewes his ambition now, (vnfortunate Fortune)
"They passe through whirle-pooles, and deepe woes doe shun,
Who the euent weigh, ere the action's done. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA V.
DIV2.STAGE: Cardinall, and Ferdinand, with a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I haue this night dig'd vp a man-drake.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: And I am growne mad with't.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: What's the progedy?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Read there, a siter dampn'd, she's loose i'th'hilt:
Growne a notorious Strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Speake lower.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Lower?
Rogues do not whisper't now, but seeke to publish't,
(As seruants do the bounty of their Lords)
Aloud; and with a couetuous searching eye,
To marke who note them: Oh confusion sease her,
She hath had most cunning baudes to serue her turne,
And more secure conueyances for lust,
Then Townes of garrison, for Seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Is't possible?
Can this be certaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Rubarbe, oh, for rubarbe
To purge this choller, here's the cursed day
To prompt my memory, and here'it shall sticke
Till of her bleeding heart, I make a spunge
To wipe it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Why doe you make your selfe
So wild a Tempest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Would I could be one,
That I might tosse her pallace 'bout her eares,
Roote vp her goodly forrests, blast her meades,
And lay her generall territory as wast,
As she hath done her honors.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Shall our blood?
(The royall blood of Arragon, and Castile)
Be thus attaincted?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Apply desperate physicke,
We must not now vse Balsamum, but fire,
The smarting cupping-glasse, for that's the meane
To purge infected blood, (such blood as hers:)
There is a kind of pitty in mie eie,
I'll giue it to my hand-kercher; and now 'tis here,
I'll bequeath this to her Bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: What to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Why, to make soft lint for his mother wounds,
When I haue hewed her to peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Curs'd creature,
Vnequall nature, to place womens hearts
So farre vpon the left-side.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Foolish men,
That ere will trust their honour in a Barke,
Made of so slight, weake-bull-rush, as is woman,
Apt euery minnt to sinke it?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Thus
Ignorance, when it hath purchas'd honour,
It cannot weild it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Me thinkes I see her laughing,
Excellent Hyenna, talke to me somewhat, quickly,
Or my imagination will carry me
To see her, in the shamefull act of sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: VVith whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Happily, with some strong thigh'd Bargeman;
Or one th'wood-yard, that can quoit the sledge,
Or tosse the barre, or else some louely Squire
That carries cole vp, to her priuy lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You lie beyond your reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Goe to (Mistris.)
'Tis not your whores milke, that shall quench my wild-fire,
But your whore a blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: How idlely shewes this rage?
VVhich carries you, as men conuai'd by witches, through the ayre,
On violent whirle-windes, this intemperate noyce,
Fitly resembles deafe-mens shrill discourse,
VVho talke aloud, thinking all other men
To haue their imperfection.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Haue not you,
My palsey?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Yes, I can be angry
VVithout this rupture, there is not in nature
A thing, that makes man so deform'd, so beastly,
As doth intemperate anger: chide your selfe,
You haue diuers men, who neuer yet exprest
Their strong desire of rest, but by vnrest,
By vexing of themselues: Come, put your selfe
In tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: So, I will onely study to seeme
The thing I am not: I could kill her now,
In you, or in my selfe, for I do thinke
It is some sinne in vs, Heauen doth reuenge
By her.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Are you starke mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I would haue their bodies
Burn't in a coale-pit, with the ventage stop'd,
That their curs'd smoake might not ascend to Heauen:
Or dippe the sheetes they lie in, in pitch or sulphure,
Wrap them in't, and then light them like a match:
Or else to boile their Bastard to a cullisse,
And giue't his leacherous father, to renew
The sinne of his backe.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I'll leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Nay, I haue done,
I am confident, had I bin damn'd in hell,
And should haue heard of this, it would haue put me
Into a cold sweat: In, in, i'll go sleepe,
Till I know who leapes my sister, i'll not stirre:
That knowne, i'll finde Scorpions to string my whips,
And fix her in a generall ecclipse. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA I.
DIV2.STAGE: Antonio, and Delio, Duchesse, Ferdinand, Bosola.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Our noble friend (my most beloued Delio)
Oh, you haue bin a stranger long at Court,
Came you along with the Lord Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I did Sir, and how faires your noble Duchesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Right fortunately well: She's an excellent
Feeder of pedegrees: since you last saw her,
She hath had two children more, a sonne, and daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Me thinkes 'twas yester-day: Let me but wincke,
And not behold your face, which to mine eye
Is somewhat leaner, verily I should dreame
It were within this halfe houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You haue not bin in Law, (friend Delio)
Nor in prison, nor a Suitor at the Court
Nor beg'd the reuersion of some great mans place,
Nor troubled with an old wife, which doth make
Your time so inseucibly hasten.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: 'Pray Sir tell me,
Hath not this newes arriu'd yet to he eare;
Of the Lord Cardinall?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I feare it hath,
The Lord Ferdinand, (that's newly come to Court,)
Doth beare himselfe right dangerously.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Pray why?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: He is so quiet, that he seemes to sleepe
The tempest out (as Dormise do in Winter,)
Those houses, that are haunted, are most still,
Till the diuell be vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: What say the common people.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: The common-rable, do directly say
She is a Strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: And your grauer heades,
(Which would he pollitique) what censure they?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: They do obserue, I grow to infinite purchase
The leaft-hand way, and all suppose the Duchesse
Would amend it, if she could: For, say they
Great Princes, though they grudge their Officers
Should haue such large, and vnconfined meanes
To get wealth vnder them, will not complaine
Least thereby they should make them odious
Vnto the people, for other obligation
Of loue, or marriage, betweene her and me,
They neuer dreame off.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: The Lord Ferdinand
Is going to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I'll instantly to bed,
For I am weary: I am to be be-speake
A husband for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: For me (Sir?) 'pray who is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: The great Count Malateste.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Fie vpon him,
A Count? he's a meere sticke of sugar-candy,
(You may looke quite thorough him) when I choose
A husband, I will marry for your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You shall do well in't: How is't (worthy Antonio?)

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: But (Sir) I am to haue priuate conference with you,
About a scandalous report, is spread
Touching mine honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Let me be euer deafe to't:
One of Pasquils paper-bullets, court calumney,
A pestilent ayre, which Princes pallaces
Are seldome purg'd off: Yet, say that it were true,
I powre it in your bosome, my fix'd loue,
Would strongly excuse, extenuate, nay deny
Faults where they apparant in you: Goe be safe
In your owne innocency.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh bless'd comfort,
This deadly aire is purg'd. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Her guilt treads on
Hot burning cultures: Now Bosola,
How thriues our intelligence?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: (Sir) vncertainly,
'Tis rumour'd she hath had three bastards, but
By whom, we may go read i'th' Starres.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Why some
Hold opinion, all things are written there.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes, if we could find Spectacles to read them,
I do suspect, there hath bin some Sorcery
Vs'd on the Duchesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Sorcery, to what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: To make her doate on some desertles fellow,
She shames to acknowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Can your faith, giue way
To thinke there's powre in potions, or in Charmes,
To make vs loue, whether we will or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Most certainely.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: A way, these are meere gullcries, horred things
Inuented by some cheating mounte-banckes
To abuse vs: Do you thinke that hearbes, or charmes
Can force the will? Some trialls haue bin made
In this foolish practise; but the ingredients
Were lenatiue poysons, such as are of force
To make the patient mad; and straight the witch
Sweares (by equiuocation, they are in loue.
The witch-craft lies in her rancke bood: this night
I will force confession from her: You told me
You had got (within these two dayes) a false key
Into her Bed-chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: As I would wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: What doe you intend to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Can you ghesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: No:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Doe not aske then:
He that can compasse me, and know my drifts,
May say he hath put a girdle 'bout the world,
And sounded all her quick-sands.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I doe not
Thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: What doe you thinke then? pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: That you are
Your owne Chronicle too much: and grosly
Flatter your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Giue me thy hand, I thanke thee:
I neuer gaue Pention but to flatterers,
Till I entertained thee: farewell,
That Friend a Great mans ruine strongely checks,
Who railes into his beliefe, all his defects. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. II.
DIV2.STAGE: Dutchesse, Antonio, Cariola, Ferdinand, Bosola, Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Bring me the Casket hither, and the Glasse;
You get no lodging here, to night (my Lord.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Indeed, I must perswade one:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Very good:
I hope in time 'twill grow into a custome,
That Noble men shall come with cap, and knee,
To purchase a nights lodging, of their wiues.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I must lye here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Must? you are a Lord of Misse-rule.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Indeed, my Rule is onely in the night.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: To what vse will you put me,

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Wee'll sleepe together:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: la, what pleasure can two Louers find in sleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: My Lord, I lye with her often: and I know
She'll much disquiet you:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: See, you are complain'd of.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: For she's the sprawlingst bedfellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I shall like her the better for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Sir, shall I aske you a question?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I pray thee Cariola.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Wherefore still when you lie with my Lady
Doe you rise so early?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Labouring men,
Count the Clocke oftnest Cariola,
Are glad when their task's ended.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I'll stop your mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Nay, that's but one, Venus had two soft Doues
To draw her Chariot: I must haue another:
When wilt thou marry, Cariola?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Neuer (my Lord.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O sic vpon this single life: forgoe it:
We read how Daphne, for her peeuish slight
Became a fruitlesse Bay-tree: Siriux turn'd
To the pale empty Reede: Anaxarate
Was frozen into Marble: whereas those
Which married, or prou'd kind vnto their friends
Were, by a gracious influence, transhap'd
Into the Oliffe, Pomgranet, Mulbery:
Became Flowres, precious Stones, or eminent Starres.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: This is a vaine Poetry: but I pray you tell me,
If there were propos'd me, Wisdome, Riches, and Beauty,
In three seuerall young men, which should I choose?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Tis a hard question: This was Paris case
And he was blind in't, and there was great cause:
For how was't possible he could iudge right,
Hauing three amorous Goddesses in view,
And they starcke naked: 'twas a Motion
Were able to be-night the apprehention
Of the seueerest Counsellor of Europe.
Now I looke on both your faces, so well form'd
It puts me in mind of a question, I would aske.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I doe wonder why hard-fauour'd Ladies
For the most part, keepe worse-fauour'd waieting women,
To attend them, and cannot endure faire-ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh, that's soone answer'd.
Did you euer in your life know an ill Painter
Desire to haue his dwelling next doore to the shop
Of an excellent Picture-maker? 'twould disgrace
His face-making, and vndoe him: I pre-thee
When were we so merry? my haire tangles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Pray-thee (Cariola) let's steale forth the roome,
And let her talke to her selfe: I haue diuers times
Seru'd her the like, when she hath chafde extreamely:
I loue to see her angry: softly Cariola. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Doth not the colour of my haire 'gin to change?
When I waxe gray, I shall haue all the Court
Powder their haire, with Arras, to be like me:
You haue cause to loue me, I entred you into my heart
Before you would vouchsafe to call for the keyes.
We shall one day haue my brothers take you napping:
Me thinkes his Presence (being now in Court)
Should make you keepe your owne Bed: but you'll say
Loue mixt with feare, is sweetest: I'll assure you
You shall get no more children till my brothers
Consent to be your Ghossips: haue you lost your tongue? 'tis wel∣come:
For know whether I am doomb'd to liue, or die,
I can doe both like a Prince. Ferdinand giues her a ponyard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Die then, quickle:
Vertue, where art thou hid? what hideous thing
Is it, that doth ecclipze thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: 'Pray sir heare me:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Or is it true, thou art but a bare name,
And no essentiall thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Doe not speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: No sir:
I will plant my soule in mine cares, to heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Oh most imperfect light of humaine reason,
That mak'st so vnhappy, to fore see
What we can least preuent: Pursue thy wishes:
And glory in them: there's in shame no comfort,
But to be past all bounds, and sence of shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I pray sir, heare me: I am married,

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: So:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Happily, not to your liking: but for that
Alas: your sheeres doe come vntimely now
To clip the birds wings, that's already flowne:
Will you see my Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yes, if I
Could change eyes with a Basilisque:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sure, you came hither
By his confideracy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: The howling of a Wolfe
Is musicke to the (schrech-Owle) pre'thee peace:
What ere thou art, that hast enioy'd my sister,
(For I am sure thou hearst me) for thine owne sake
Let me not know thee: I came hither, prepar'd
To worke thy discouery: yet am now perswaded
It would beget such violent effects
As would dampe vs both: I would not for ten Millions
I had beheld thee: therefore vse all meanes
I neuer may haue knowledge of thy name;
Enioy thy lust still, and a wretched life,
On that condition: And for thee (vilde woman,)
If thou doe wish thy Leacher may grow old
In thy Embracements, I would haue thee build
Such a roome for him, as our Anchorites
To holier vse enhabite: Let not the Sunne
Shine on him, till he's dead: Let Dogs, and Monkeys
Onely conuerse with him, and such dombe things
To whom Nature denies vse, to sound his name.
Doe not keepe a Paraqueto, least she learne it;
If thou doe loue him, cut out thine owne tongue
Least it bewray him.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Why might not I marry?
I haue not gone about, in this, to create
Any new world, or custome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Thou art vndone:
And thou hast ta'ne that massiy sheete of lead
That hid thy husbands bones, and foulded it
About my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Mine bleedes for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ford.
SP.L: Thine? thy heart?
What should I nam't, vnlesse a hollow bullet
Fill'd with vnquenchable wild-fire?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: You are, in this
Too strict: and were you not my Princely brother
I would say to wilfull: My reputation
Is safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Dost thou know what reputation is
I'll tell thee, to small purpose, since th'instruction
Comes now too late:
Vpon a time Reputation, Loue, and Death,
Would trauell ore the world: and it was concluded
That they should part, and take three seuerall wayes:
Death told them, they should find him in great Battailes:
Or Cities plagu'd with plagues: Loue giues them councell
To enquire for him 'mongst vnambitious shepheards,
Where dowries were not talk'd of: and sometimes
'Mongst quiet kindred, that had nothing left
By their dead Parents: stay (quoth Reputation)
Doe not forsake me: for it is my nature
If once I part from any man I meete
I am neuer found againe: And so, for you:
You haue shooked hands with Reputation,
And made him inuisible: So fare you well.
I will neuer see you more.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Why should onely I,
Of all the other Princes of the World
Be cas'de-vp, like a holy Relique? I haue youth,
And a litle beautie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: So you haue some Virgins,
Th are Wches: I will neuer see thee more. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: You saw this apparition.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes: we are
Betraid; how came he hither? I should turne
This, to thee, for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Pray sir doe: and when
That you haue clft my heart, you shall read there,
Mine innocence:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: That Gallery gaue him entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I would this terrible thing would come againe,
That (standing on my Guard) I might relate
My warrantable loue: ha, what meanes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: He left this with me: she shewes the poniard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: And it seemes, did wish
You would vse it on your selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: His Action
Seem'd to intend so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: This hath a handle to't,
As well as a point, turne it towards him,
And so fasten the keene edge, in his rancke gall:
How now? who knocks? more Earthquakes?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I stand
As if a Myne, beneath my feete, were ready
To be blowne vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: 'Tis Bosola:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Away,
Oh misery, me thinkes vniust actions
Should weare these masques, and curtaines; and not we:
You must instantly part hence: I haue fashion'd it already. Ex. Ant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: The Duke your brother is ta'ne vp in a whirle wind
Hath tooke horse, and's rid poast to Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: So late?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: He told me, (as he mounted into th'sadle,)
You were vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Indeed, I am very neere it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Antonio, the master of our house-hold
Hath dealt so falsely with me, in's accounts:
My brother stood engag'd with me for money
Ta'ne vp of certaine Neopolitane Iewes,
And Antonio let's the Bonds be forfeyt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Sange: this is cunning:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: And hereupon
My brothers Bills at Naples are protested
Against: call vp our Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I shall. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: The place that you must flye to, is Ancona,
Hire a house there. I'll send after you
My Treasure, and my Iewls: our weake safetie
Runnes vpon engenous wheeles: short sillables,
Must stand for periods: I must now accuse you
Of such a fained crime, as Tasso calls
Magnanima Mensogna: a Noble Lie,
'Cause it must shield our honors: harke they are comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Will your Grace heare me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I haue got well by you: you haue yeelded me
A million of losse; I am like to inherit
The peoples curse for your Stewardship:
You had the tricke, in Audit time to be sicke,
Till I had sign'd your Quietus; and that cur'de you
Without helpe of a Doctor. Gentlemen,
I would haue this man be an example to you all:
So shall you hold my fauour: I pray let him;
For h'as done that (alas) you would not thinke of,
And (because I intend to be rid of him)
I meane not to publish: vse your fortune else-where.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I am strongely arm'd to brooke my ouer-throw,
As commonly men beare with a hard yeere:
I will not blame the cause on't; but doe thinke
The necessitie of my maleuolent starre
Procures this, not her humour: O the inconstant,
And rotten ground of seruice, you may see:
'Tis eu'n like him, that in a winter night
Takes a long slumber, ore a dying sie;
A-loth to part from't: yet parts thence as cold,
As when he first sat downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: We doe confifcate
(Towards the satisfying of your accounts)
All that you haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I am all yours: and 'tis very fit
All mine should be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: So, sir; you haue your Passe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You may see (Gentlemen) what 'tis to serue
A Prince with body, and soule. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Heere's an example, for extortion; what moysture, is drawne out of the Sea, when fowle weather comes, powres downe, and runnes into the Sea againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I would know what are your opinions
Of this Antonio.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Offi.
SP.L: He could not abide to see a Pigges head gaping,
I thought your Grace would finde him a Iew:

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Offi.
SP.L: I would you had bin his Officer, for your owne sake.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Offi.
SP.L: You would haue had more money.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Offi.
SP.L: He stop'd his eares with blacke wooll: and to (those came a woman.
To him for money) said he was thicke of hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Offi.
SP.L: Some said he was an hermophrodite, for he could not abide

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Offi.
SP.L: How scuruy prowd he would looke, when the Treasury was full:
Well, let him goe:

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Offi.
SP.L: Yes, and the chippings of the Buttrey fly after him,
To scowre his gold Chaine. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Leaue vs: what doe you thinke of these?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: That these are Rogues; that in's prosperitie,
But to haue waited on his fortune, could haue vvish'd
His dutty Stirrop rited through their noses:
And follow'd after's Mue, like a Beare in a Ring.
Would haue prostituted their daughters, to his Lust:
Made their first-borne and Intelligencers: thought none happy
But such as vvere borne vnder his bless'd Plannet:
And vvore his Liuory: and doe these Lyce drop off now?
Well, neuer looke to haue the like againe;
He hath left a sort of slattring rogues, behind him,
Their doombe must follow: Princes pay flatterers,
In their owne money: Flatterers dissemble their vices,
And they dissemble their lies, that's Iustice:
Alas, poore gentlemen,

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Poore? he hath amply fill'd his coses.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Sure he was too honest: Pluto the god of riches,
When he's sent (by Iupiter) to any man
He goes limping, to signifie that wealth
That comes on god's name, comes slowly, but when he's sent
One the diuells arrand, he rides poast, and comes in by settles▪
Let me shew you, what a most vnlu'd iewell,
You haue (in a wanton humour) throwne away,
To blesse the man shall find him: He was an excellent
Courtier, and most faithfull, a souldier, that thought it
As beastly to know his owne value too little,
As deuillish to acknowledge it too much,
Both his vertue, and forme, deseru'd a farre better fortune:
His discourse rather delighted to iudge it selfe, then shew it selfe.
His breast was fill'd with all perfection,
And yet it seem'd a priuate whispring roome.
It made so little noyse of't.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: But he was basely descended.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Will you make your selfe a mercinary herald,
Rather to examine mens pedegrees, then vertues?
You shall want him,
For know an honest states-man to a Prince,
Is like a Cedar, planted by a Spring,
The Spring bathes the trees roote, the gratefull tree,
Rewards it with his shadow: you haue not done so,
I would sooner swim to the Bermoothes on two Politisians
Rotten bladders, tide together with an Intelligence hart-string
Then depend on so changeable a Princes fauour.
Fare-thee-well (Antonio) since the mallice of the world
Would needes downe with thee, it cannot be sayd yet
That any ill happened vnto thee, considering thy all,
Was accompanied with vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Oh, you render me excellent Musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: This good one that you speake of, is my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Do I not dreame? can this ambitious age
Haue so much goodnes in't, as to prefer
A man, meerely for worth: without these shadowes
Of wealth, and painted honors? possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I haue had three children by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Fortunate Lady,
For you haue made your priuate nuptiall bed
