The humble, and faire Seminary of peace,
No question but: many an vnbenific'd Scholler
Shall pray for you, for this deed, and reioyce
That some preferment in the world can yet
Arise from merit. The virgins of your land
(That haue no dowries) shall hope, your example
Will raise them to rich husbands: Should you want
Souldiers 'twould make the very Turkes and Moores
Turne Christians, and serue you for this act.
Last, the neglected Poets of your time,
(In honour of this trophee of a man,
Rais'd by that curious engine, (your white hand)
Shall thanke you, in your graue for't; and make that
More reuerend then all the Cabinets
Of liuing Princes: For Antonio
His fame, shall likewise flow, from many a pen,
When Heralds shall want coates, to sell to men.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: As I taste comfort, in this friendly speech,
So would I finde concealement.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: O the secret of my Prince.
Which I will weare on th'in-side of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: You shall take charge of all my coyne, and iewels,
And follow him, for he retires himselfe
To Ancona.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Whether, within few dayes,
I meane to follow thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let me thinke:
I would wish your Grace, to faigne a Pilgrimage
To our Lady of Loretto, (scarce seauen leagues
From faire Ancona) so may you depart
Your Country, with more honour, and your flight
Will seeme a Princely progresse, retaining
Your vsuall traine about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sir, your direction
Shall lead me, by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: In my opinion,
She were better progresse to the bathes
At Leuca, or go visit the Spaw
In Germany, for (if you will beleeue me)
I do not like this iesting with religion,
This faigned Pilgrimage.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thou superstitious foole,
Prepare vs instantly for our departure:
Past sorrowes, let vs moderately lament them,
For those to come, seeke wisely, to preuent them. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: A Polititian is the diuells quilted anvell,
He fashions all sinnes on him, and the blowes
Are neuer heard, he may worke in a Ladies Chamber,
(As here for proofe) what rests, but I reueale
All to my Lord? oh, this base quality
Of Intelligencer? why, euery Quality i'th'world
Preferres but gaine, or commendation:
Now for this act, I am certaine to be rais'd,
"And men that paint weedes, (to the life) are prais'd. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA III.
DIV2.STAGE: Cardinall, Ferdinand, Mallateste, Pescara, Siluia, Delio, Bosola.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Must we turne Souldier then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: The Emperour,
Hearing your worth that way, (ere you attain'd
This reuerend garment,) ioynes you in commission
With the right fortunate souldier, the Marquis of Pescara,
And the famous Lanoy.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: He that had the honour
Of taking the French King Prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: The same,
Here's a plot drawne, for a new Fortification,
At Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: This great Count Malastete, I perceiue
Hath got employment?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: No employment (my Lord)
A marginall note in the muster-booke, that he is
A voluntary Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: He's no Souldier?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: He ha's worne gun-powder, in's hollow tooth, for the tooth-ache.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: He comes to the leaguer, with a full intent,
To eate fresh beefe, and garlicke, meanes to stay
Till the sent begon, and straight returne to Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: He hath read all the late seruice,
As the City Chronicle relates it,
And keepe two Pewterers going, onely to expresse
Battailes in modell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Then hel; fight by the booke.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: By the Almanacke, I thinke
To choose good dayes, and shun the Criticall▪
That's his mistris skarfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: Yes, he protests
He would do much for that taffita,

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I thinke he would run away from a battaile
To saue it from taking prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: He is horribly afraid,
Gun-powder will spoile the perfume on't,

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I saw a Duch-man breake his pate once
For calling him pot-gun, he made his head
Haue a boare in't, like a musket.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: I would he had made a touch-hole to't.
He is indeede a guarded sumpter-cloath
Onely for the remooue of the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: Bosola arriu'd? what should be the businesse?
Some falling out amongst the Cardinalls.
These factions amongst great men, they are like
Foxes, when their heads are deuided
They carry fire in their tailes, and all the Country
About them, goes to wracke for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: What's that Bosola?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I knew him in Padua, a fantasticall scholler,
Like such, who studdy to know how many knots was in
Hercules club, of what colour Ahilles beard was,
Or whether Hector were not troubled with the tooth-ach,
He hath studdied himselfe halfe bleare-ei'd, to know the
True semitry of Caesars nose by a shooing-horne, and this
He did to gaine the name of a speculatiue man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: Marke Prince Ferdinand,
A very Salamander liues in's eye,
To mocke the eager violence of fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sil.
SP.L: That Cardinall hath made more bad faces with his oppression
Then euer Michael Angelo made good ones,
He lifts vp's nose, like a fowle Por-pisse before a storme,

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: The Lord Ferdinand laughes.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Like a deadly Cannon,
That lightens ere it smoakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: These are your true pangues of death,
The pangues of life, that strugle with great states-men,

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: In such a deformed silence, witches whisper their charmes.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Doth she make religion her riding hood
To keepe her from the sun, and tempest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: That: that damnes her: Me thinkes her fault, and
Beauty blended together, shew like leaprosie
The whiter, the fowler: I make it a question
Whether her beggerly brats were euer christned.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I will instantly sollicite the state of Ancona
To haue them banish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are for Lorett?
I shall not be at your Ceremony: fare you well,
Write to the Duke of Malfy, my yong Nephew,
She had by her first husband, and acquaint him,
With's mothers honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Antonio?
A slaue, that onely smell'd of yncke, and coumptets,
And neu'r in's like, look'd like a Gentleman,
But in the audit time, go, go presently,
Draw me out an hundreth and fifty of our horse,
And meete me at the fort-bridge. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA IIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Two Pilgrimes to the Shrine of our Lady of Loretto.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: I haue not seene a goodlier Shrine then this,
Yet I haue visited many.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pilg.
SP.L: The Cardinall of Arragon
Is, this day to resigne his Cardinals hat,
His sister Duchesse likewise is arriu'd
To pay her vow of Pilgrimage, I expect
A noble Ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: No question: —They come.

DIV2.STAGE: Here the Ceremony of the Cardinalls enstalment, in the habit a Souldier: perform'd in deliuering vp his Crosse, Hat, Robes, and Ring, at the Shne; and inuesting him with Sword, Helmet, Sheeld and purs: Then Antonio, the Duchesse, and their Children, (hauing presented themselues at the Shrine) are (by a forme of Banishment in dumbe-shew, expressed to∣wards them by the Cardinall, and the State of Ancona) bani∣shed: During Ceremony, this Ditty is sung (to very sollemne Musique) by diuers Church-men, and then Exeunt.

LG.L: Armes, and Honors, decke thy story,
To thy Fames eternall glory,
Aduerse Fortune euer flie-thee,The Au∣thor dis∣claimes this Ditty to be his.
No disastrous fate come nigh-thee.
I alone will sing thy praises,
Whom to honour, vertue raises;
And thy study, that diuine-is,
Bent to Marshiall discipline-is:
Lay aside all those robes lie by thee,
Crown thy arts, with armes: they'll beautifie thee.
O worthy of worthiest name, adorn'd in this manner,
Lead brauely thy forces on, vnder wars warlike banner▪
O mayst thou proue fortunate, in all Marshiall courses:
Guide thou still, by skill, in artes, and forces:
Victory attend thee nigh whilst fame sings loud thy powres,
Triumphant conquest crowne thy head, and blessings powre downe showres.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: Here's a strange turne of state, who would haue thought
So great a Lady, would haue match'd her selfe
Vnto so meane a person? yet the Cardinall
Beares himselfe much too cruell.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pilg.
SP.L: They are banish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: But I would aske what power hath this state
Of Ancona to determine of a free Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pilg.
SP.L: They are a free state sir, and her brother shew'd
How that the Pope fore-hearing of her loosenesse,
Hath seaz'd into th'protection of the Church
The Dukedome, which she held as dowager.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pil.
SP.L: But by what iustice?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pilg.
SP.L: Sure I thinke by none,
Only her brothers instigation.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: What was it, with such violence he tooke
Of from her finger?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Pil.
SP.L: 'Twas her wedding ring,
Which he vow'd shortly he would sacrifice
To his reuenge.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pilg.
SP.L: Alasse Antonio,
If that a man be thrust into a well,
No matter who sets hand to't, his owne weight
Will bring him sooner to th'bottome: Come, let's hence.
Fortune makes this conclusion generall,
"All things do helpe th'unhappy man to fall. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA V.
DIV2.STAGE: Antonio, Duchesse, Children, Cariola, Seruants, Bosola, Souldiers, with Vizards.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Banish'd Ancona?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes, you see what powre
Lightens in great mens breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Is all our traine
Shrunke to this poore remainder?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: These poore men,
(Which haue got little in your seruice) vow
To take your fortune: But your wiser buntings
Now they are sledg'd are gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: They haue done wisely,
This puts me in minde of death, Physitians thus,
With their hands full of money, vse to giue ore
Their Patients.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Right the fashion of the world,
From decaide fortunes, euery flatterer shrinkes,
Men cease to build, where the foundation sinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I had a very strange dreame to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What was't?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Me thought I wore my Coronet of State▪
And on a sudaine all the Diamonds
Were chang'd to Pearles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My Interpretation
Is, you'll weepe shortly, for to me, the pearles
Doe signifie your teares:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: The Birds, that liue i'th field
On the wilde benefit of Nature, liue
Happier then we; for they may choose their Mates,
And carroll their sweet pleasures to the Spring:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You are happily ore-ta'ne.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: From my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes, from the Lord Ferdinand; your brother,
All loue, and safetie

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Thou do'st blanch mischiefe
Wouldst make it white: See, see; like to calme weather
At Sea, before a tempest, false hearts speake faire
To those they intend most mischiefe.
A Letter. Send Antonio to me; I want his head in a busines: (a poli∣ticke equiuocation)
He doth not want your councell, but your head;
That is, he cannot sleepe till you be dead.
And here's annother Pitfall, that's strew'd ore
With Roses: marke it, 'tis a cunning one.

L.HI: I stand ingaged for your husband, for seuerall debts at Naples: let not
That trouble him, I had rather haue his heart, then his mony.

SP.L: And I beleeue so too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: What doe you beleeue?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: That he so much distrusts my husbands loue,
He will by no meanes beleeue his heart is with him
Vntill he see it: The Diuell is not cunning enough
To circumuent vs in Ridles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Will you reiect that noble, and free league
Of amitie, and loue which I present you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Their league is like that of some politick Kings
Onely to make themselues of strength, and powre
To be our after-ruine: tell them so;

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And what from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Thus tell him: I will not come.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And what of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My brothers haue dispers'd
Blood-hounds abroad; which till I heare are muzell'd
No truce, though hatch'd with nere such politick skill
Is safe, that hangs vpon our enemies will.
I'll not come at them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: This proclaimes your breeding.
Euery small thing, drawes a base mind to feare:
As the Adamant drawes yron: fare you well sir,
You shall shortly heare from's. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I suspect some Ambush:
Therefore by all my loue; I doe coniure you
To take your eldest sonne, and flye towards Millaine;
Let vs not venture all this poore remainder
In one vnlucky bottom.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You councell safely:
Best of my life, farewell: Since we must part
Heauen hath a hand in't: but no otherwise,
Then as some curious Artist, takes in sunder
A Clocke, or Watch, when it is out of frame
To bring't in better order.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I know not which is best,
To see you dead, or part with you: Farewell Boy.
Thou art happy, that thou hast not vnderstanding
To know thy misery: For all our wit
And reading, brings vs to a truer sence
Of sorrow: In the eternall Church, Sir,
I doe hope we shall not part thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh, be of comfort,
Make Patience a noble fortitude:
And thinke not how vnkindly we are vs'de:
"Man (like to Cassia) is prou'd best, being bruiz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Must I like to a slaue-borne Russian,
Account it praise to suffer tyranny?
And yet (O Heauen) thy heauy hand is in't.
I haue seene my litle boy, oft scourge his top,
And compar'd my selfe to't: naught made me ere go right,
But Heauens scourge-sticke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Doe not weepe:
Heauen fashion'd vs of nothing: and we striue,
To bring our selues to nothing: farewell Cariola,
And thy sweet armefull: if I doe neuer see thee more,
Be a good Mother to your litle ones,
And saue them from the Tiger: fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Let me looke vpon you once more: for that speech
Came from a dying father: your kisse is colder
Then that I haue seene an holy Anchorite
Giue to a dead mans skull.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My heart is turnde to a heauy lumpe of lead,
With which I sound my danger: fare you well. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: My Laurell is all withered.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Looke (Madam) what a troope of armed men
Make toward vs. Enter Bosola with a Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: O, they are very welcome:
When Fortunes wheele, is ouer-charg'd with Princes,
The waight makes it moue swift. I wonld haue my ruine
Be sudden: I am your aduenture, am I not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You are, you must see your husband no more,

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: What Diuell art thou, that counterfeits heauens thunder?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Is that terrible? I would haue you tell me
Whether is that note worse, that frights the silly birds
Out of the corne or that which doth allure them
To the nets? you haue hearkned to the last too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: O misery: like to a rusty ore-char'd Carnon,
Shall I neuer slye in peeces? come: to what Prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: To one▪

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Whether then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: To your Pallace.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I haue heard that Charons boate, serues to conuay
All ore the dismall Lake, but brings none backe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Your brothers meane you, safety, and pitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Pitie? with such a pitie men preserue aliue
Pheasmes, and Quailes, when they are not fat enough
To be eaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: These are your children?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch
SP.L: Yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Can they pratle?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: No:
But I intend, since they were borne accurd;
Cursses shall be their first language.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Fye (Madam)
Forget this base, low-fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Were I a man:
I'll'd beat that counterfeit face, into thy other

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: One of no Birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Say that he was borne meane.
Man is most happy, when's owne actions
Be arguments, and examples of his Vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: A barren, beggerly vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I pre-thee who is greatest, can you tell?
Sad tales befit my woe: I'll tell you one.
A Salmon, as she swam vnto the Sea,
Met with a Dog-fish; who encounters her
With this rough language: why art thou so bold
To mixe thy selfe with our high state of floods
Being no eminent Courtier, but one
That for the calmest, and fresh time o'th' yeere
Do'st liue in shallow Riuers, rank'st thy selfe
With silly Smylts, and Shrympes? and darest thou
Passe by our Dog-ship, without reuerence?
O (Quoth the Salmon) sister, be at peace:
Thanke Iupiter, we both haue pass'd the Net,
Our value neuer can be truely knowne,
Till in the Fishers basket we be showne,
I'th' Market then my price may be the higher,
Euen when I am neerest to the Cooke, and fire.
So, to Great men, the Morrall may be stretched.
,,Men oft are valued high, when th'are most wretch'd.
But come: whether you please: I am arm'd 'gainst misery:
Bent to all swaies of the Oppressors will.
There's no deepe Valley, but neere some great Hill. Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: How doth our sister Dutchesse beare her selfe
In her imprisonment?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Nobly: I'll describe her:
She's sad, as one long vs'd to't: and she seemes
Rather to welcome the end of misery
Then shun it: a behauiour so noble,
As giues a maiestie to aduersitie:
You may discerne the shape of louelinesse
More perfect, in her teares, then in her smiles;
She will muse foure houres together: and her silence,
(Me thinkes) expresseth more, then if she spake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Her mellancholly seemes to be fortifide
With a strange disdaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: 'Tis so: and this restraint
(Like English Mastiffes, that grow feirce with tying)
Makes her too passionately apprehend
Those pleasures she's kept from.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Curse vpon her:
I will no longer study in the booke
Of anothers heart: informe her what I told you. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: All comfort to your Grace;

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I will haue none:
'Pray-thee, why do'st thou wrap thy poysond Pilles
In Gold, and Sugar?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Your elder brother the Lord Ferdinand
Is come to visite you: and sends you word
'Cause once he rashly made a solemne vowe
Neuer to see you more; he comes i'th' night:
And prayes you (gently) neither Torch, nor Taper
Shine in your Chamber: he will kisse your hand:
And reconcile himselfe: but, for his vowe,
He dares not see you:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: At his pleasure:
Take hence the lights: he's come.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Here sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: This darkenes suites you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I would aske you pardon:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You have it;
For I account it, the honorabl'st reuenge
Where I may kill, to pardon: where are your Cubbs?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Call them your children;
For though our nationall law, distinguish Bastards
From true legitimate issue: compassionate nature
Makes them all equall.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Doe you visit me for this?
You violate a Sacrament o'th' Church
Shall make you howle in hell for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: It had bin well,
Could you haue liu'd thus alwayes: for indeed
You were too much i'th' light: But no more,
I come to seale my peace with you: here's a hand, gives her a dead mans hand.
To which you haue vow'd much loue: the Ring vpon't
You gaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I affectionately kisse it:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: 'Pray doe: and bury the print of it in your heart:
I will leaue this Ring with you, for a Loue-token:
And the hand, as sure as the ring: and doe not doubt
But you shall haue the heart too: when you need a friend
Send it to him, that ow'de it: you shall see
Whether he can ayd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: You are very cold.
I feare you are not well after your trauell:
Hah? lights: oh horrible:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Let her haue lights enough Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: What witch-craft doth he practise, that he hath left
A dead-mans hand here? — Here is discouer'd, (behind a Trauers;) the artificiall figures of Antonio, and his children, ap∣pearing as if they were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Looke you: here's the peece, from which 'twas t'e;
He doth present you this sad spectacle,
That now you know directly they are dead,
Hereafter you may (wisely) cease to grieue
For that which cannot be recouered.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: There is not betweene heauen, and earth one wish
I stay for after this: it wastes me more,
Then were't my picture, fashion'd out of wax,
Stucke with a magicall needle, and then buried
In some fowle dung-hill: and yond's an excellent property
For a tyrant, which I would account mercy,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: If they would bind me to that liueles truncke,
And let me freeze to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Come, you must liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: That's the greatest torture soules feele in hell,
In hell: that they must liue, and cannot die:
Portia, I'll new kindle thy Coales againe,
And reuiue the rare, and almost dead example
Of a louing wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: O sye: despaire? remember
You are a Christian.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: The Church enioynes fasting:
I'll starue my selfe to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Leaue this vaine sorrow;
Things being at the worst, begin to mend:
The Bee when he hath shot his sting into your hand
May then play with your eye-lyd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Good comfortable fellow
Perswade a wretch that's broke vpon the wheele
To haue all his bones new set: entreate him liue,
To be executed againe: who must dispatch me?
I account this world a tedious Theatre,
For I doe play a part in't 'gainst my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Come, be of comfort, I will saue your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Indeed I haue not leysure to tend so small a busi∣nes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Now, by my life, I pitty you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Thou art a foole then,
To wast thy pitty on a thing so wretch'd
As cannot pitty it: I am full of daggers:
Puffe: let me blow these vipers from one.
What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: One that wishes you long life.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I would thou wert hang'd for the horrible curse
Thou hast giuen me: I shall shortly grow one
Of the miracles of pitty: I'll goe pray: No,
I'll goe curse:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh fye:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: I could curse the Starres.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh fearefull:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: And those three smyling seasons of the yeere
Into a Russian winter: nay the world
To its first Chaos.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Looke you, the Starres shine still:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Oh, but you must remember, my curse hath a great way to goe:
Plagues, (that make lanes through largest families)
Consume them:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Fye Lady:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Let them like tyrants
Neuer be remembred, but for the ill they haue done:
Let all the zealous prayers of mortefied
Church-men forget them,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: O vncharitable:

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Let heauen, a little while, cease crowning Martirs
To punish them: Goe, howle them this: and say I long to bleed
,,It is some mercy, when men kill with speed. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Excellent; as I would wish: she's plagu'd in Art.
These presentations are but fram'd in wax.
By the curious Master in that Qualitie,
Vincentio Lauriola, and she takes them
For true substantiall Bodies.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why doe you doe this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: To bring her to despaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: 'Faith, end here:
And go no farther in your cruelty,
Send her a penetentiall garment, to put on,
Next to her delicate skinne, and furnish her
With beades, and prayer bookes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Damne her, that body of hers,
While that my blood ran pure in't, was more worth
Then, that which thou wouldst comfort, (call'd a soule)
I will send her masques of common Curtizans,
Haue her meate seru'd vp by baudes, and ruffians,
And ('cause she'll needes be mad) I am resolu'd
To remoue forth the common Hospitall,
All the mad-folke, and place them neere her lodging:
There let them practise together, sing, and daunce,
And act their gambols to the full o'th'moone:
If she can sleepe the better for it, let her,
Your worke is almost ended.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Must I see her againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You must.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Neuer in mine owne shape,
That's forfeited, by my intelligence,
And this last cruell lie: when you send me next,
The businesse shalbe comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Very likely,
Thy pity is nothing of kin to thee: Antonio,
Lurkes about Millaine, thou shalt shortly thither,
To feede a fire, as great as my reuenge,
Which neu'r will slacke, till it haue spent his fuell,
"Intemperate agues, make Physitians cruell. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA II.

STAGE.HI: Duchesse, Cariola, Seruant, Mad-men, Bosola, Exeioners, Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Wha oyse was that?
Of Mad-men (Lady) which your Tyrant brother
Hath plac'd about your lodging: This tyranny,
I thinke was neuer practis'd till this howre.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Indeed I thanke him: nothing but noyce, and folly
Can keepe me in my right wits, whereas reason
And silence, make me starke mad: Sit downe,
Discourse to me some dismall Tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: O 'twill encrease your mellancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thou art deceiu'd,
To heare of greater griefe, would lessen mine,
This is a prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Yes, but you shall liue
To shake this durance off.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thou art a foole,
The Robin red-brest, and the Nightingale,
Neuer liue long in cages.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Pray drie your eyes.
What thinke you of Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Of nothing▪
When I muse thus, I sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Like a mad-man, with your eyes open?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Do'st thou thinke we shall know one an other,
In th'other world?

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Yes, out of question.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: O that it were possible we might
But hold some two dayes conference with the dead.
From them, I should learne somewhat I am sure
I neuer shall know here: I'll tell thee a miracle,
I am not mad yet, to my cause of sorrow.
Th'heauen ore my head, seemes made of molton brasse.
The earth of flaming sulphure, yet I am not mad:
I am acquainted with sad misery,
As the tan'd galley-slaue, is with his Oare,
Necessity makes me suffer constantly,
And custome makes it easie, who do I looke like now?

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Like to your picture in the gallery,
A deale of life in shew, but none in practise:
Or rather like some reuerend monument
Whose ruines, are euen pittied.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Very proper:
And Fortune seemes onely to haue her eie-sight,
To behold my Tragedy: How now,
What noyce is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Seruant.
SP.L: I am come to tell you,
Your brother hath entended you some sport:
A great Physitian, when the Pope was sicke
Of a deepe mellancholly, presented him
With seuerall sorts of mad-men, which wilde obiect
(Being full of change, and sport,) forc'd him to laugh,
And so th'impost-hume broke: the selfe same cure,
The Duke intends on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Let them come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: There's a mad Lawyer, and a secular Priest,
A Doctor that hath forfeited his wits
By iealousie: an Astrologian,
That in his workes, sayd such a day o'th'moneth,
Should be the day of doome; and fayling of't,
Ran mad: an English Taylor, crais'd i'th'braine,
With the studdy of new fashion: a gentleman vsher
Quite beside himselfe, with care to keepe in minde,
The number of his Ladies salutations;
Or how do you, she employ'd him in each morning:
A Farmer too, (an excellent knaue in graine)
Mad, 'cause he was hindred transportation,
And let one Broaker, (that's mad) loose to these,
Youl'd thinke the diuell were among them.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Sit Cariola: let them loose when you please,
For I am chain'd to endure all your tyranny.

DIV2.STAGE: Here (by a Mad-man) this song is sung, to a dismall kind of Musique.

LG.L: O let vs howle, some heauy note,
some deadly-dogged howle,
Sounding, as from the threatning throat,
of beastes, and fatall fowle.
As Rauens, Schrich-owles, Bulls, and Beares,
We'll bill, and bawle our parts,
Till yerk some noyce haue cloy'd your eares,
and coasiu'd your hearts.
At last when as our quire wants breath,
our bodies being blest,
We'll sing like Swans, to welcome death,
and die in loue and rest.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Mad-man.
SP.P: Doomes-day not come yet? I'll draw it neerer by a perspectiue, or make a glasse, that shall set all the world on fire vpon an instant: I cannot sleepe, my pillow is stuff't with a littour of Porcupines.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Mad.
SP.P: Hell is a meere glasse-house, where the diuells are continually blowing vp womens soules, on hollow yrons, and the fire neuer goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Mad.
SP.L: I will lie with euery woman in my parish the tenth night:
I will tithe them ouer like hay-cockes.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Mad.
SP.L: Shall my Pothecary out-go me, because I am a
Cuck-old? I haue found out his roguery: he makes allom
Of his wiues vrin, and sells it to Puritaines, that haue sore
Throates with ouer-strayning.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Mad.
SP.L: I haue skill in Harroldry.
Hast?
You do giue for your creast, a wood-cockes head, with the
Braines pickt out on't, you are a very ancient Gentleman.
Greeke is turn'd Turke, we are onely to be sau'd by the
Heluetian translation.
Come on Sir, I will lay the law to you.
Oh, rather lay a coraziue, the law will eate to the bone.
He that drinkes but to satisfie nature is damn'd.
If I had my glasse here, I would shew a sight should make
All the women here, call me mad Doctor.
What's he, a rope-maker?
No, no, no, a snufling knaue, that while he shewes the
Tombes, will haue his hand in a wenches placket.
Woe, to the Caroach, that brought home my wife from
The Masque, at three a clocke in the morning, it had a large
Feather-bed in it.
I haue paired the diuells nayles forty times, roasted them
In Rauens egges, and cur'd agues with them.
Get me three hundred milch bats, to make possets▪
To procure sleepe.
All the Colledge may throw their caps at me, I haue made a
Soape-boyler costiue, it was my master-peece: —Here the Daunce consisting of 8. Mad-men, with musicke answerable there unto, after which, Bosola (like an old man) enters.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Is he mad to?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: 'Pray question him: I'll leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I am come to make thy tombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Hah, my tombe?
Thou speak'st, as if I lay vpon my death bed,
Gasping for breath: do'st thou perceiue me sicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes, and the more dangerously, since thy sicknesse is insensible.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thou art not mad sure, do'st know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Who am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thou art a box of worme-seede at best, but a saluatory
Of greene mummey: what's this flesh? a little cruded milke,
Phantasticall puffe-paste: our bodies are weaker then those
Paper prisons boyes vse to keepe flies in: more contemptible:
Since ours is to preserue earth-wormes: didst thou euer see
A Larke in a cage? such is the soule in the body: this world
Is like her little turfe of grasse, and the Heauen ore our heades,
Like her looking glasse, onely giues vs a miserable knowledge
Of the small comsse of our prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Am not I, thy Duchesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thou art some great woman sure, for riot begins to sit on thy
Fore-head (clad in gray haires) twenty yeares sooner, then on a
Merry milke mydes. Thou sleep'st worse, then if a mouse
Should be forc'd to take vp her lodging in a cats eare:
A little infant, that breedes it's teeth, should it lie with thee, would
Crie out, as if thou wert the more vnquiet bed-fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I am Duchesse of Malfy still.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: That makes thy sleepes so broken:
"Glories (like glowe-wormes) a farre off, shine bright,
But look'd to neere, haue neither heate, nor light.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Thou art very plaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: My trade is to flatter the dead, not the liuing
I am a tombe-maker.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: And thou com'st to make my tombe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Let me be a little merry,
Of what stuffe wilt thou make it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Nay, resolue me first, of what fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Why, do we grow phantasticall in our death-bed?
Do we affect fashion in the graue?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Most ambitiously: Princes images on their tombes,
Do not lie, as they were wont, seeming to pray,
Vp to heauen: but with their hands vnder their cheekes,
(As if they died of the tooth-ache) they are not carued
With their eies, fix'd vpon the starres; but as their
Mindes were wholy bent vpon the world,
The selfe-same way they seeme to turne their faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Let me know fully therefore the effect
Of this thy dismall preparation,
This talke, fit for a charnell?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Now, I shall,
Here is a present from your Princely brothers, A Coffin, Cords, and a Bell.
And may it arriue wel-come, for it brings
Last benefit, last sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Let me see it,
I haue so much obedience, in my blood,
I wish it in ther veines, to do them good.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: This is your last presence Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: O my sweete Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Peace, it affrights not me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I am the common Bell-man,
That vsually is sent to condemn'd persons▪
The night before they suffer:

SP.SPEAKER: Duch
SP.L: Euen now thou said'st,
Thou wast a tombe-maker?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: 'Twas to bring you
By degree to mortification: Listen.
Hearke, now euery thing is still,
The Schritch-Owle, and the whistler shrill,
Call vpon our Dame, aloud,
And bid her quickly don her shrowd:
Much you had of Land and rent,
Your length in clay's now competent.
A long war, disturb'd your minde,
Here your perfect peace is sign'd,
Of what is't, fooles make such vaine keeping?
Sin their conception, their birth, weeping:
Their life, a generall mist of error,
Their death, a hideous storme of terror,
Strew your haire, with powders sweete:
D'on cleane linnen, bath your feete,
And (the foule feend more to checke)
A crucifixe let blesse your necke,
'Tis now full tide, 'tweene night, and day,
End your groane, and come away.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Hence villaines, tyrants, murderers: alas!
What will you do with my Lady? call for helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: To whom, to our next neighbours? they are mad-folkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Remooue that noyse.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Farwell Cariola,
In my last will, I haue not much to giue
A many hungry guests, haue fed vpon me,
Thine will be a poore reuersion.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: I will die with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I pray-thee looke thou giu'st my little boy
Some sirrop, for his cold, and let the girle
Say her prayers, ere she sleepe. Now what you please,
What death?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Strangling, here are your Executioners.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: I forgiue them:
The apoplexie, cathar, or cough o'th'loongs,
Would do as much as they do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Doth not death fright you?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Who would be afraid on't?
Knowing to meete such excellent company
In th'other world.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yet, me thinkes,
The manner of your death should much afflict you,
This cord should terrifie you?

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Not a whit,
What would it pleasure me, to haue my throate cut
With diamonds? or to be smothered
With Cssia? or to be shot to death, with pearles?
I know death hath ten thousand seuerall doores
For men to take their Exits: and 'tis found
They go on such strange geometricall hinges,
You may open them both wayes: any way, (for heauen sake)
So I were out of your whispering: Tell my bothers,
That I erceiue death, (now I am well a wake)
Best guift is, they can giue, or I can take,
I would faine put off my last womans-fault,
Il'd not be tedious to you.
We are ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Dispose my breath, how please you, but my body
Bestow vpon my women, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Exec.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Duch.
SP.L: Pull, and pull strongly, for your able strength,
Most pull downe heauen vpon me:
Yet stay, heauen gates are not so highly arch'd
As Princes pallaces, they that enter there
Must go vpon their knees: Come violent death,
Serue for Mandragora, to make me sleepe;
Go tell my brothers, when I am laid out, They strangle her.
They then may feede in quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Where's the waiting woman?
Fetch her: Some other strangle the children:
Looke you, there sleepes your mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: Oh you are damn'd
Perpetually for this: My turne is next,
Is't not so ordered?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes, and I am glad
You are so well prepar'd for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: You are deceiu'd Sir,
I am not prepar'd for't, I will not die,
I will first come to my answere; and know
How I haue offended.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Come, dispatch her:
You kept her counsell, now you shall keepe ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cari.
SP.L: I will not die, I must not, I am contracted
To a young Gentle-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Exec.
SP.L: Here's your wedding Ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Let me but speake with the Duke: I'll discouer
Treason to his person.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Delayes: throttle-her.

SP.SPEAKER: Exec.
SP.L: She bites: and scratches:

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: If you kill me now
I am damn'd: I haue not bin at Confession
This two yeeres:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: When.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I am quicke with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why then,
Your credit's sau'd: beare her in toth' next roome:
Let this lie still.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Is she dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Shee is what
You'll'd haue her: But here begin your pitty, Shewes the children strangled▪
Alas, how haue these offended?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: The death
Of young Wolffes, is neuer to be pittied.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Fix your eye here:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Constantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Doe you not weepe?
Other sinnes, onely speake; Murther shreikes out:
The Element of water, moistens the Earth,
But blood flies vpwards, and bedewes the Heauens.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Couer her face: Mine eyes dazell she di'd yong.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I thinke not so: her infelicitie
Seem'd to haue yeeres too many.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: She, and I were Twinnes:
And should I die this instant, I had liu'd
Her Time to a Mynute.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: It seemes she was borne first:
You haue bloodely approu'd the auncient truth,
That kindred commonly doe worse agee
Then remote strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Let me see her face againe;
Why didst not thou pitty her: what an excellent
Honest man, might'st thou haue bin
If thou hadst borne her to some Sactuary?
Or (bold in a good cause) oppos'd thy selfe
With thy aduanced sword aboue thy head,
Betweene her Innocence, and my Reuenge?
I bad thee, when I was distracted of my wits▪
Goe kill my dearest friend, and thou hast don't.
For let me but examine well the cause;
What was the meanenes of her match to me▪
Onely I must confesse, I had a hope
(Had she continu'd widow) to haue gain'd
An infinite masse of Treasure by her death:
And that was the mayne cause; her Marriage,
That drew a streame of gall, quite through my heart;
For thee, (as we obserue in Tragedies
That a good Actor many times is curss'd
For playing a villaines part) I hate thee for't:
And (for my sake) say thou hast done much ill, well:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let me quicken your memory: for I perceiue
You are falling into ingratitude: I challenge
The reward due to my seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I'll tell thee,
What I'll giue thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Doe:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I'll giue thee a pardon
For this murther:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Hh?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yes: and 'tis
The largest bounty I can studie to doe thee.
By what authority did'st thou execute
This bloody sentence?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: By your

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Mine? was I her Iudge?
Did any ceremoniall forme of Law,
Doombe her to not-Being? did a compleat Iury
Deliuer her conuiction vp i'th Court?
Where shalt thou find this Iudgement registerd
Vnlesse in hell? See: like a bloody foole
Th'hast forfeyted thy life, and thou shalt die for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: The Office of Iustice is peruerted quite
When one Thiefe hangs another: who shall dare
To reueale this:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Oh, I'll tell thee:
The Wolfe shall finde her Graue, and scrape it vp:
Not to deuoure the corpes, but to discouer
The horrid murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You; not I shall quake for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Leaue me:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I will first receiue my Pention.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are a villaine:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: When your Ingratitude
Is Iudge, I am so;

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: O horror!
That not the feare of him, which bindes the diuels
Can prescribe man obedience.
Neuer looke vpon me more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Why fare thee well▪
Your brother, and your selfe, are worthy men;
You haue a paire of hearts, are hollow Graues,
Rotten, and rotting others: and your vengeance,
(Like two-chain'd bullets) still goes arme in arme,
You may be Brothers: for treason, like the plague,
Doth take much in a blood: I stand like one
That long hath ta'ne a sweet, and golden dreame.
I am angry with my selfe, now that I wake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Get thee into some vnknowne part o'th▪ world
That I may neuer see thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Let me know
Wherefore I should be thus neglected? sir,
I seru'd your tyranny: and rather stroue,
To satisfie your selfe, then all the world;
And though I loath'd the euill, yet I lou'd
You that did councell it: and rather sought
To appeare a true seruant, then an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I'll goe hunt the Badger by Owle-light:
'Tis a deed of darkenesse. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: He's much distracted: Off my painted honour,
While with vaine hopes, our faculties we tyre,
We seeme to sweate in yee, and freeze in fire;
What would I doe, wee this to doe againe?
I would not change my peace of conscience
For all the wealth of Europe: She stirres; here's life:
Returne (faire soule) from darkenes, and lead mine
Out of this sencible Hell: She's warme, she breathes:
Vpon thy pale lips I will melt my heart
To store them with fresh colour: who's there?
Some cordiall drinke: Alas! I dare not call:
So pitty, would destroy pitty: her Eye opes,
And heauen in it, seemes to ope, (that late was shut)
To take me vp to merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Antonio.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes (Madam) he is liuing,
The dead bodies you saw, were but faign'd statues;
He's reconcil'd to your brothers: the Pope hath wrought
The attonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch.
SP.L: Mercy. she dies,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh, she's gone againe: there the cords of life broake:
Oh sacred Innocence, that sweetely sleepes
On Turtles feathers: whil'st a guilty conscience
Is a blacke Register, wherein is writ
All our good deedes, and bad: a Perspectiue
That showes vs hell; that we cannot be suffer'd
To doe good when we haue a mind to it?
This is manly sorrow:
These teares, I am very certaine, neuer grew
In my Mothers Milke. My estate is suncke
Below the degree of feare: where were
These penitent fountaines, while she was liuing?
Oh, they were frozen vp: here is a sight
As direfull to my soule, as is the sword
Vnto a wretch hath slaine his father: Come, I'll beare thee hence.
And execute thy last will; that's deliuer
Thy body to the reuerend dispose
Of some good women: that the cruell tyrant
Shall not denie me: Then I'll poast to Millaine,
Where some what I will speedily enact
Worth my deiection. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What thinke you of my hope of reconcilement
To the Aragonian brethren?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I misdoubt it
For though they haue sent their letters of safe conduct
For your repaire to Millaine, they appeare
But Nets, to entrap you: The Marquis of Pescara,
Vnder whom you hold certaine land in Cheit,
Much 'gainst his noble nature, hath bin mou'd
To ceize those lands, and some of his dependants
Are at this instant, making it their suit
To be inuested in your Reuenewes.
I cannot thinke, they meane well to your life,
That doe depriue you of your meanes of life,
Your liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You are still an heretique.
To any safety, I can shape my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Here comes the Marquis: I will make my selfe
Petitioner for some part of your land,
To know whether it is flying.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I pray doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Sir, I haue a suit to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: To me.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: An easie one:
There is the Cittadell of St. Bennet,
With some demeasnes, of late in the possession
Of Antonio Bologna, please you bestow them on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: You are my friend: But this is such a suit,
Nor fit for me to giue, nor you to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: No sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: I will giue you ample reason for't,
Soone in priuate: Here's the Cardinalls Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: My Lord, I am growne your poore Petitioner,
And should be an ill begger, had I not
A Great mans letter, here (the Cardinalls)
To Court you in my fauour.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: He entreates for you
The Cittadell of Saint Bennet, that belong'd
To the banish'd Bologna.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: I could not haue thought of a friend, I could
Rather pleasure with it: 'tis yours:

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Sir, I thanke you:
And he shall know how doubly I am engag'd
Both in your gut, and speedinesse of giuing,
Which makes your graunt, the greater. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How they fortefie
Themselues with my ruine?

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Sir: I am
Litle bound to you:

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Why.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Because you denide this suit, to me, and gau't
To such a creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Doe you know what it was?
It was Antonios land: not forfeyted
By course of lawe; but rauish'd from his throate
By the Cardinals entreaty: it were not fit
I should bestow so maine a peece of wrong
Vpon my friend: 'tis a gratification
Onely due to a Strumpet: for it is iniustice;
Shall I sprinckle the pure blood of Innocents
To make those followers, I call my friends
Looke ruddier vpon me? I am glad
This land, (ta'ne from the owner by such wrong)
Returnes againe vnto so fowle an vse,
As Salary for his Lust. Learne, (good Delio)
To aske noble things of me, and you shall find
I'll be a noble giuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: You instruct e well:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant
SP.L: Why, here's a man, now, would fright impudence
From sawciest Beggers.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Prince Ferdinand's come to Millaine
Sicke (as they giue out) of an Appoplexie:
But some say, 'tis a frenzie; I am going
To visite him. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Tis a noble old fellow:

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: What course doe you meane to take, Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: This night, I meane to venture all my fortune
(Which is no more, then a poore lingring life)
To the Cardinals worst of mallice: I haue got
Priuate accesse to his chamber: and intend
To visit him, about the mid of night.
(As once his brother did our noble Dutchesse.)
It may be that the sudden apprehension
Of danger (for I'll goe in mine owne shape)
When he shall see it fraight with loue, and dutie,
May draw the poyson out of him, and worke
A friendly reconcilement; if it faile;
Yet, it shall rid me of this infamous calling,
For better fall once, then be euer falling.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I'll second you in all danger: and (how ere)
My life keepes rancke with yours

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You are still my lou'd, and best friend. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. II.
DIV2.STAGE: Pescara, a Doctor, Ferdinand, Cardinall, Malateste, Bosola, Iulia.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Now Doctor; may I visit your Patient?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.L: If't please your Lordship: but he's instantly
To take the ayre here in the Gallery,
By my direction.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: 'Pray-thee, what's his disease?

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.L: A very pestilent disease (my Lord)
They call Licanthropia.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: What's that?
I need a Dictionary to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.L: I'll tell you:
In those that are possess'd with't there ore-flowes
Such mellencholy humour, they imagine
Themselues to be transformed into Woolues,
Steale forth to Church-yards in the dead of night,
And dig dead bodies vp: as two nights since
One met the Duke, 'bout midnight in a lane
Behind St. Markes Church, with the leg of a man
Vpon his shoulder; and he howl'd fearefully:
Said he was a Woolffe: onely the difference
Was, a Woolffes skinne was hairy on the out-side,
His on the In-side: bad them take their swords,
Rip vp his flesh, and trie: straight I was sent for,
And hauing ministerd to him, found his Grace
Very well recouered.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: I am glad on't,

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.L: Yet not without some feare
Of a relaps: if he grow to his fit againe
I'll goe a neerer way to worke with him
Then euer Paraclesus dream'd of: If
They'll giue me leaue I'll buffet his madnesse out of him.
Stand aside: he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Leaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Why doth your Lordship loue this solitarines?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Eagles cōmonly fly alone: They are Crowes, Dawes, and
Sterlings that flocke together: Looke, what's that,
Followes me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Nothing (my Lord)

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: 'Tis your shadow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Stay it, let it not haunt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Impossible; if you moue, and the Sun shine:

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I will throtle it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Oh, my Lord: you are angry with nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: You are a foole:
How is't possible I should catch my shadow
Vnlesse I fall vpon't? When I goe to Hell,
I meane to carry a bribe: for looke you
Good guifts euer-more make away, for the worst persons

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Rise good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I am studying the Art of Patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: 'Tis a noble Vertue;

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: To driue six Snailes before me, from this towne
To Mosco; neither vse Goad, nor Whip to them,
But let them take their owne time: (the patientst mani'th' world
Match me for an experiment) and I'll crawle after
Like a sheepe-biter.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Force him vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Vse me well, you were best:
What I haue don, I haue don: I'll confesse nothing▪

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.L: Now let me come to him: Are you mad
(My Lord?) are you out of your Princely wits?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: What's he?

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: Your Doctor..

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Let me haue his beard saw'd off, and his eye
Browes fil'd more ciuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: I must do mad trickes with him,
For that's the onely way on't. I haue brought
Your grace a Salamanders skin, to keepe you
For sun-burning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I haue cruell sore eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: The white of a Cockatrixes-egge is present remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Let it be a new layd one, you were best:
Hide me from him: Phisitians are like Kings,
They brooke no contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Now he begins to feare me,
Now let me alone with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: How now, put off your gowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Let me haue some forty vrinalls fill'd with Rose-water:
He, and I'll go pelt one an other with them,
Now he begins to feare me: Can you fetch a friske, sir?
Let him go, let him go vpon my perrill:
I finde by his eye, he stands in awe of me,
I'll make him, as tame as a Dormouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Can you fetch your friskes, sir: I will stamp him into a Cullice:
Flea off his skin, to couer one of the Anotomies,
This rogue hath set i'th'cold yonder, in Barber-Chyrurgeons hall:
Hence, hence, you are all of you, like beasts for sacrifice,
There's nothing left of you, but tongue, and belly,
Flattery, and leachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: Doctor, he did not feare you throughly.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: True, I was somewhat to forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Mercy vpon me, what a fatall iudgement
Hath falne vpon this Ferdinand?

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: Knowes your grace
What accident hath brought vnto the Prince,
This strange distraction?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I must faigne somewhat: Thus they say it grew.
You haue heard it rumor'd for these many yeares,
None of our family dies, but there is seene
The shape of an old woman, which is giuen
By tradition, to vs, to haue bin murther'd
By her Nephewes, for her riches: Such a figure
One night (as the Prince sat vp late at's booke)
Appear'd to him, when crying out for helpe,
The gentlemen of's chamber, found his grace
All on a cold sweate, alter'd much in face
And language: Since which apparition,
He hath growne worse, and worse, and I much feare
He cannot liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Sir, I would speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: We'll leaue your grace,
Wishing to the sicke Prince, our noble Lord,
All health of minde, and body.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You are most welcome:
Are you come? so: this fellow must not know
By any meanes I had intelligence
In our Duchesse death: For (though I counsell'd it,)
The full of all th'ingagement seem'd to grow
From Ferdinand: Now sir, how fares our sister?
I do not thinke but sorrow makes her looke
Like to an ot-'d garment: She shall now
Tast comfort from me: why do you looke so wildely?
Oh, the fortune of your master here, the Prince
Deiects you, but be you of happy comfort:
If you'll do on thing for me, I'll entreate
Though he had a cold tombe-stone ore his bones,
I'll'd make you what you would be.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Any thing,
Giue it me in a breath, and let me slie to't:
They that thinke long, small expedition win,
For mung much o'th'end, cannot begin.
Sir, will you come in to Supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I am busie, leaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: What an excellent shape hath that fellow? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: 'Tis thus: Antonio lurkes here in Millaine,
Enquire him out, and kill him: while he liues,
Our sister cannot marry, and I haue thought
Of an excellent match for her: do this, and stile me
Thy aduancement.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: But by what meanes shall I find him out?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: There is a gentleman, call'd Delio
Here in the Campe, that hath bin long approu'd
His loyall friend: Set eie vpon that fellow,
Follow him to Masse, may be Antonio,
Although he do account religion
But a Schoole-name, for fashion of the world,
May accompany him, or else go enquire out
Delio's Confessor, and see i you can bribe
Him to reueale it: there are a thousand wayes
A man might find to trace him: As to know,
What fellowes haunt the Iewes, for taking vp
Great summes of money, for sure he's in want,
Or else to go to th'Picture-makers, and learne
Who brought her Picture lately, some of these
Happily may take —

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Well, I'll not freeze i'th'businesse,
I would see that wretched thing, Antonio
Aboue all sightes i'th'world.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Do, and be happy. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: This fellow doth breed Bazalisques in's eies,
He's nothing else, but murder: yet he seemes
Not to haue notice of the Duchesse death:
'Tis his cunning: I must follow his example,
There cannot be a surer way to trace,
Then that of an old Fox.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: So, sir, you are well met.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Nay, the doores are fast enough:
Now Sir, I will make you confesse your treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Treachery?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Yes, confesse to me
Which of my women 'twas you hyr'd, to put
Loue-powder into my drinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Loue powder?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Yes, when I was at Malfy,
Why should I fall in loue with such a face else?
I haue already suffer'd for thee so much paine,
The onely remedy to do me good,
Is to kill my longing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Sue your Pistoll holds
Nothing but perfumes, or kissing comfits: excellent Lady,
You haue a pritty way on't to discouer
Your longing: Come, come, I'll disarme you,
And arme you thus, yet this is wondrous strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Compare thy forme, and my eyes together,
You'll ind my loue no such great miracle: Now you'll say,
I am wanton: This nice modesty, in Ladies
Is but a troublesome familiar,
That haunts them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Know you me, I am a blunt souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: The better,
Sure, there wants fire, where there are no liuely sparkes
Of roughnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And I want complement.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Why ignorance in court-ship cannot make you do amisse,
If you haue a heart to do well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You are very faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Nay, if you lay beauty to my charge,
I must plead vnguilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Your bright eyes
Carry a Quiuer of darts in them, sharper
Then Sun-beames.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You will mar me with commendation,
Put your selfe to the charge of courting me,
Whereas now I woe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue it, I will worke vpon this Creature,
Let vs grow most amorously familiar:
If the great Cardinall now should see me thus,
Would he not count me a villaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: No, he might count me a wanton,
Not lay a scruple of offence on you:
For if I see, and steale a Diamond,
The fault is not i'th'stone, but in me the thiefe,
That purloines it: I am sudaine with you,
We that are great women of pleasure, vse to cut off
These vncertaine wishes, and vnquiet longings,
And in an instant ioyne the sweete delight
And the ptty excuse together: had you bin in'th'streete,
Vnder my chamber window, euen there
I should haue courted you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh, you are an excellent Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Bid me do somewhat for you presently,
To expresse I loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I will, and if you loue me,
Faile not to effect it: The Cardinall is growne wondrous mel∣lancholly,
Demand the cause, let him not put you off,
With faign'd excuse, discouer the maine ground on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Why would you know this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue depended on him,
And I heare that he is falne in some disgrace
With the Emperour, if he be, like the mice
That forsake falling houses, I would shift
To other dependance.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You shall not neede follow the warres,
I'll be your maintenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And I your loyall seruant,
But I cannot leaue my calling.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Not leaue an
Vngratefull Generall, for the loue of a sweete Lady?
You are like some, cannot sleepe in feather-beds,
But must haue blockes for their pillowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Will you do this?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Cunningly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: To morrow I'll expect th'intelligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: To morrow? get you into my Cabinet,
You shall haue it with you: do not delay me,
No more then I do you: I am like one
That is condemn'd: I haue my pardon promis'd.
But I would see it seal'd: Go, get you in,
You shall see me winde my tongue about his heart,
Like a skeine of silke.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Seru.
SP.L: Here.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Let none vpon your liues
Haue conference with the Prince Ferdinand,
Vnlesse I know it: In this distraction
He may reueale the murther:
Yond's my lingring consumption:
I am weary of her; and by any meanes
Would be qui off.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: How now, my Lord?
What ailes you?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Oh, you are much alterd:
Come, I must be your Secretary, and remoue
This lead from off your bosome, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I may not tell you▪

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Are you so farre in loue with sorrow,
You cannot part, with part of it? or thinke you
I cannot loue your grace, when you are sad,
As well as merry? or do you suspect
I, that haue bin a secret to your heart,
These many winters, cannot be the same
Vnto your tongue?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Satisie thy longing,
The onely way to make thee keepe my councell,
Is not to tell thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Tell your eccho this,
Or flatterers, that (like ecchoes) still report
What they heare (though most imperfect) and not me:
For, if that you be true vnto your selfe,
I'll know.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Will you racke me?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: No, iudgement shall
Draw it from you: It is an equall fault,
To tell ones secrets, vnto all, or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: The first argues folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: But the last tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Very wel, why imagine I haue committed
Some secret deed, which I desire the world
May neuer heare of?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Therefore may not I know it?
You haue conceal'd for me, as great a sinne
As adultery: Sir, neuer was occasion
For perfect triall of my constancy
Till now: Sir, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You'll repent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: It hurries thee to ruine: I'll not tell thee,
Be well aduis'd, and thinke what danger 'tis
To receiue a Princes secrets: they that do,
Had neede haue their breasts hoop'd with adamant
To containe them: I pray thee yet be satisfi'd,
Examine thine owne frailety, 'tis more easie
To tie knots, then vnloose them: 'tis a secret
That (like a lingring poyson) may chance lie
Spread in thy vaines, and kill thee seauen yeare hence▪

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Now you dally with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: No more, thou shalt know it.
By my appointment, the great Duchesse of Malfy,
And two of her young children, foure nights since
Were strangled.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Oh heauen! (sir) what haue you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: How now? how setles this? thinke you your
Bosome will be a graue, darke and obscure enough
For such a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You haue vndone your selfe (sir.)

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: VVhy?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: It lies not in me to conceale it.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: No? come, I will sweare you to't vpon this booke▪

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Most religiously.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Kisse it.
Now you shall neuer vtter it, thy curiosity
Hath vndone thee: thou'rt poyson'd with that booke,
Because I knew thou couldst not keepe my councell,
I haue bound the to't by death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: For pitty sake, hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Ha, Bosola?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I forgiue you,
This equall peece of Iustice you haue done:
For I betraid your councell to that fellow,
He ouer heard it; that was the cause I said
It lay not in me, to conceale it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh foolish woman,
Couldst not thou haue poyson'd him?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: 'Tis weakenesse,
Too much to thinke what should haue bin done,
I go, I know not whether.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Wherefore com'st thou hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: That I might finde a great man, (like your selfe,)
Not out of his wits (as the Lord Ferdinand)
To remember my seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I'll haue thee hew'd in peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Make not your selfe such a promise of that life
Which is not yours, to dispose of.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Who plac'd thee here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Her lust, as she intended.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Very well, now you know me for your fellow murderer▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: And wherefore should you lay faire marble colours,
Vpon your rotten purposes to me?
Vnlesse you imitate some that do plot great Treasons,
And when they haue done, go hide themselues i'th' graues,
Of those were Actors in't?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: No more,
There is a fortune attends thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Shall I go sue to fortune any longer?
'Tis the fooles Pilgrimage.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I haue honors in store for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: There are a many wayes that conduct to seeming
Honor, and some of them very durty ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Throw to the diuell
Thy mellancholly, the fire burnes well,
VVhat neede we keepe a stirring of and make
A greater smoother? thou wilt kill Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Take vp that body.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I thinke I shall
Shortly grow the common Beare, for Church-yards?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I will allow thee some dozen of attendants,
To aide thee in the murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Oh, by no meanes,
Phisitians that apply horse-leiches to any rancke swelling,
Vse to cut of their tailes, that the blood may run through them
The faster: Let me haue no traine, when I goe to shed blood,
Least it make me haue a greater, when I ride to the Gallowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Come to me after midnight, to helpe to remoue that body
To her owne Lodging: I'll giue out she dide o'th' Plague;
'Twill breed the lesse enquiry after her death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Where's Castruchio, her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: He's rod to Naples to take possession
Of Antonio's Cittadell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Beleeue me, you haue done a very happy turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Faile not to come: There is the Master-key
Of our Lodgings: and by that you may conceiue
What trust I plant in you. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: You shall find me ready.
Oh poore Antonio, though nothing be so needfull
To thy estate, as pitty, Yet I finde
Nothing so dangerous: I must looke to my footing;
In such slippery ye-pauements, men had neede
To be frost-nayld well: they may breake their neckes else.
The President's here afore me: how this man
Beares vp in blood? seemes feareles? why, 'tis well:
Securitie some men call the Subuts of Hell,
Onely a dead wall betweene. Well (good Antonio)
I'll seeke thee out; and all my care shall be
To put thee into safety from the reach
Of these most cruell biters, that haue got
Some of thy blood already. It may be,
I'll ioyne with thee, in a most iust reuenge.
The weakest Arme is strong enough, that strikes
With the sword of Iustice: Still me thinkes the Dutchesse
Haunts me: there, there▪ 'tis nothing but my mellancholy.
O Penitence, let me truely tast thy Cup.
That throwes men downe, onely to raise them vp. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. III.
DIV2.STAGE: Antonio, Delio, Eccho, (from the Dutchesse Graue.)

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Yond's the Cardinall's window: This fortification
Grew from the ruines of an auncient Abbey:
And to yond fide o'th' riuer, lies a wall
(Peec of a Cloyster) which in my opinion
Giues the best Eccho, that you euer heard;
So hollow, and so dismall, and withall
So plaine in the destinction of our words,
That many haue supposde it is a Spirit
That answeres.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I doe loue these auncient ruynes▪
We neuer tread vpon them, but we set
Our foote vpon some reuerend History▪
And questionles, here in this open Court
(Which now lies naked to the iniuries
Of stormy weather) some men lye Enterr'd
Lou'd the Church so well, and gaue so largely to't,
They thought it should haue canopide their Bones
Till Doombes-day: But all things haue their end:
Churches, and Citties (which haue diseases like to men)
Must haue like death that we haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Like death that we haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Now the Eccho hath caught you:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: It groan'd (me thought) and gaue
A very deadly Accent?

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Deadly Accent.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I told you 'twas a pretty one: You may make it
A Huntes-man, or a Faulconer, a Musitian,
Or a Thing of Sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: A Thing of Sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I sur that suites it best.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: That suites it best.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Tis very like my wiues voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: I, wifes-voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Come: let's vs walke farther from't:
I Would not haue you go toth' Cardinalls to night:
Doe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Doe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Wisdome doth not more moderate, wasting Sorrow
Then time: take time for't: be mindfull of thy safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Be mindfull of thy safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Necessitie compells me:
Make scruteny throughout the passes
Of your owne life; you'll find it impossible
To flye your fate.
O flye your fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Harke: the dead stones seeme to haue pitty on you
And giue you good counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Eccho, I will not talke with thee;
For thou art a dead Thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Thou art a dead Thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: My Dutchesse is asleepe now,
And her litle-Ones, I hope sweetly: oh Heauen
Shall I neuer see her more?

SP.SPEAKER: Eccho.
SP.L: Neuer see her more:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I mark'd not one repetition of the Eccho
But that: and on the sudden, a cleare light
Presented me a face folded in sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Your fancy; meerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Come: I'll be out of this Ague;
For to liue thus, is not indeed to liue:
It is a mockery, and aase of life,
I will not henceforth saue my selfe by halues,
Loose all, or nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: Your owne vertue saue you:
I'll fetch your eldest sonne; and second you:
It may be that the sight of his owne blood
Spred in so sweet a figure, may beget
The more compassion.
How euer, fare you well:
Though in our miseries, Fortune haue a part,
Yet, in our noble suffrings, she hath none,
Contempt of paine, that we may call our owne. Exe.

STAGE.HI: Cardinall, Pescara, Malatest, Rodorigo, Grisolan, Bosola, Ferdinand, Antonio, Seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: You shall not watch to night by the sicke Prince,
His Grace is very well recouer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Good my Lord suffer vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Oh, by no meanes:
The noyce, and change of obiect in his eye,
Doth more distract him: I pray, all to bed,
And though you heare him in his violent fit▪
Do not rise, I intreate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: So sir, we shall not,

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Nay, I must haue you promise
Vpon your honors, for I was enioyn'd to't
By himselfe; and he seem'd to vrge it sencibly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: Let out honors bind this trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Nor any of your followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: It may be to make triall of your promise
When he's a sleepe, my selfe will rise, and faigne
Some of his mad trickes, and crie out for helpe,
And faigne my selfe in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: If your throate were cutting,
I'll'd not come at you, now I haue protested against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Why, I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.L: 'Twas a forle storme to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: The Lord Ferdinand's chamber, shooke like an Ozier.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: 'Twas nothing but pure kindnesse in the Diuell,
To ocke his owne child. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: The reason why I would not suffer these
About my brother, is, because at midnight
I may with better priuacy, conuay
Iulias body, to her owne Lodging: O, my Conscience!
I would pray now: but the Diuell takes away my heart
For hauing any confidence in Praier.
About this houre, I appointed Bosola
To fetch the body: when he hath seru'd my turne,
He dies. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Hah? 'twas the Cardinalls voyce: I heard him name,
Bosola, and my death: listen, I heare ones footing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Strangling is a very quiein death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Nay then I see, I must stand vpon my Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: What say' to that? whisper, softly: doe you agree to't?
So it must be done i'th' darke: the Cardinall
Would not for a thousand pounds, the Doctor should see it. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: My death is plotted; here's the consequence of murther.
"We value not desert, nor Christian breath,
When we know blacke deedes, must be cur'de with death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Here stay Sir, and be confident, I pray:
I'll fetch you a darke Lanthorne. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Could I take him at his prayers,
There were hope of pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Fall right my sword:
I'll not giue thee so much leysure, as to pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh, I am gone: Thou hast ended a long suit,
In a mynut.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: What art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: A most wretched thing,
That onely haue thy benefit in death,
To appeare my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Where are you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Very neere my home: Bosola?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Oh misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Smother thy pitty, thou art dead else: Antonio?
The man I would haue sau'de 'boue mine owne life?
We are meerely the Starres tennys-balls (strooke, and banded
Which way please them) oh good Antonio,
I'll whisper one thing in thy dying eare,
Shall make thy heart breake quickly: Thy faire Dutchesse
And two sweet Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Their very names
Kindle a litle life in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Are murderd!

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Some men haue wish'd to die.
At the hearing of sad tydings: I am glad
That I shall do't in sadnes: I would not now
Wish my wounds balm'de, nor heal'd: for I haue no vse
To put my life to: In all our Quest of Greatnes;
(Like wanton Boyes, whose pastime is their care)
We follow after bubbles, blowne in th'ayre.
Pleasure of life, what is't? onely the good houres
Of an Ague: meerely a preparatiue to rest,
To endure vexation: I doe not aske
The processe of my death: onely commend me
To Delio.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Breake heart:

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: And let my Sonne, flie the Courts of Princes,

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thou seem'st to haue lou'd Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: I brought him hether,
To haue reconcil'd him to the Cardinall.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I doe not aske thee that:
Take him vp, if thou tender thine owne life,
And beare him, where the Lady Iulia
Was wont to lodge: Oh, my fate moues swift.
I haue this Cardinall, in the forge already,
Now I'll bring him to th'hammer▪ (O direfull misprision:)
I will not Imitate things glorious,
No more then base: I'll be mine owne example.
On, on: and looke thou represent, for silence,
The thing thou bear'st. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. V.
DIV2.STAGE: Cardinall (with a Booke) Bosola, Pescara, Malateste, Rodorigo. Ferdinand, Delio, Seruant with Antonio's body.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: I am puzzell'd in a question about hell:
He saies, in hell, there's one materiall fire,
And yet it shall not burne all men alike.
Lay him by: How tedious is a guilty conscience?
When I looke into the Fish-ponds, in my Garden,
Me thinkes I see a thing, arm'd with a Rake
That seemes to strike at me: Now? art thou come? thou look'st ghastly:
There sits in thy face, some great determination,
Mix'd with some feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thus it lightens into Action:
I am come to kill thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Hah? helpe: our Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thou art deceiu'd:
They are out of thy howling.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Hold: and I will faithfully deuide
Reuenewes with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Thy prayers, and proffers
Are both vnseasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Raise the Watch: we are betraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: I haue confinde your flight:
I'll suffer your retreyt to Iulias Chamber,
But no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Helpe: we are betraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Listen:

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: My Dukedome, for rescew.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Fye vpon his counterfeyting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Why, 'tis nor the Cardinall.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Yes, yes, 'tis he:
But I'll see him hang'd, ere I'll goe downe to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Here's a plot vpon me, I am assaulted: I am lost▪
Vnlesse some rescew.

SP.SPEAKER: Gris.
SP.L: He doth this pretty well:
But it will not serue; to laugh me out of mine honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: The sword's at my throat:

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: You would not bawle so lowd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Come, come: lets's goe to bed: he told vs thus much afore∣hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Pesc.
SP.L: He wish'd you should not come at him: but beleeu't,
The accent of the voyce sounds not in iest.
I'll downe to him, howsoeuer, and with engines
Force ope the doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: Let's follow him aloofe,
And note how the Cardinall will laugh at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: There's for you first: 'cause you shall not vnbarracade the doore
To let in rescew. He kills the Seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: What cause hast thou to pursue my life?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Looke there:

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Slaine by my hand vnwittingly:
Pray, and be sudden: when thou kill'dst thy sister,
Thou tookst from Iustice her most equall bce,
And left her naught but her sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: O mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Now it seemes thy Greatnes was onely outward:
For thou fall'st faster of thy selfe, then calamitie
Can driue thee: I'll not wast longer time: There

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Thou hast hurt me:

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Againe:

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Shall I die like a Leoret
Without any resistance? helpe, helpe, helpe:
I am slaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Th'allarum? giue me a fresh horse:
Rally the vaunt-guard: or the day is lost:
Yeeld, yeeld: I giue you the honour of Armes,
Shake my Sword ouer you, will you yeilde?

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Helpe me, I am your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: The diuell?
My brother fight vpon the aduerse party? He wounds the Cardinall, and (in the scuffle) giues Bosola his death wound.
There flies your ransome.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Oh Iustice:
I suffer now, for what hath former bin:
"Sorrow is held the eldest child of sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Now you're braue followes:
Caesars Fortune was harder then Pompeys:
Caesar died in the armes of prosperity,
Pompey at the feete of disgrace: you both died in the field,
The paine's nothing: paine many times, is taken away, with
The apprehension of greater, (as the tooth-ache with the ight
Of a Barbor, that comes to pull it out) there's Philosophy for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Now my reuenge is perfect: sinke (thou maine cause
Of my vndoing) the last part of my life,
Hath done me best seruice. He kills Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Giue me some wet hay, I am broken winded,
I do account this world but a dog-kennell:
I will vault credit, and affect high pleasures,
Beyond death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: He seemes to come to himselfe, now he's so neere the bottom▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: My sister, oh! my sister, there's the cause on't.
" Whether we fall by ambition, blood, or lust,
" Like Diamonds, we are cut with our owne dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Thou hast thy payment too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Yes, I hold my weary soule, in my teeth,
'Tis ready to part from me: I do glory
That thou, which stood'st like a huge Piramid
Begun vpon a large, and ample base,
Shalt end in a little point a kind of nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: How now (my Lord?)

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Oh sad disastre.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: How comes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: Reuenge, for the Duchesse of Malfy, murdered
By th'Aragonian brethren: for Antonio,
Slaine by his hand: for lustfull Iulia,
Poyson'd by this man: and lastly, for my selfe,
(That was an Actor in the maine of all,
Much 'gainst mine owne good nature, yet i'th'end
Neglected.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: How now (my Lord?)

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Looke to my brother:
He gaue vs these large wounds, as we were strugling
Here i'th' rushes: And now, I pray, let me
Be layd by, and neuer thought of.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: How fatally (it seemes) he did withstand,
His owne rescew?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Thou wretched thing of blood,
How came Antonio by his death?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.L: In a mist: I know not how,
Such a mistake, as I haue often seene
In a play: Oh, I am gone,
We are onely like dead wals, or vaulted graues,
That ruin'd, yeildes no eccho: Fare you well,
It may be paine: but no harme to me to die,
In so good a quarrell: Oh this gloomy world,
In what a shadow, or deepe pit of darknesse,
Doth (womanish, and fearefull) mankind liue?
Let worthy mindes, nere stagge in distrust
To suffer death, or shame for what is iust,
Mine is an other voyage.

SP.SPEAKER: Pes.
SP.L: The noble Delio, as I came to th'Pallace,
Told me of Antonio's being here, and shew'd me
A pritty gentlemen his sonne and heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Oh Sir, you come to late.

SP.SPEAKER: Del.
SP.L: I heard so, and
Was arm'd for't ere I came: Let vs make noble vse
Of this great ruine; and ioyne all our force
To establish this yong hopefull Gentleman
In's mothers right. These wretched eminent things
Leaue no more fame behind 'em, then should one
Fall in a frost, and leaue his print in snow,
As soone as the sun shines, it euer melts,
Both forme, and matter: I haue euer thought
Nature doth nothing so great, for great men,
As when she's pleas'd, to make them Lords of truth:
"Integrity of life, is fames best friend,
Which noblely (beyond Death) shall crowne the end. Exeunt.
